item.title: UFO (British TV series)
item.description:
UFO (British TV series) ðŸ”—

A British science fiction television series that aired from 1970 to 1971, focusing on Earth’s defense against an alien invasion in the then-future of 1980.

Premise ðŸ”—

In 1980, Earth is under threat from aliens from a dying planet who are abducting humans for their organs. SHADO (Supreme Headquarters Alien Defence Organisation), a secret international military agency operating under the guise of a movie studio, is formed to defend Earth. SHADO utilizes advanced technology, including a space intruder detection satellite (SID), lunar interceptors, a submarine/aircraft called Skydiver, and ground-based SHADO Mobiles. The aliens are humanoid, requiring a green oxygenated liquid and special contact lenses. Their UFOs can travel faster than light but have limited time in Earth’s atmosphere.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

The series features a large ensemble cast with frequent changes. Ed Bishop as Commander Ed Straker is the only actor to appear in every episode.

Main characters ðŸ”—

  • Commander Edward Straker (Ed Bishop): The head of SHADO, posing as the head of Harlington-Straker Film Studios.
  • Colonel Paul Foster (Michael Billington): A former test pilot recruited into SHADO.
  • Lieutenant Gay Ellis (Gabrielle Drake): Moonbase commander.
  • Colonel Alec Freeman (George Sewell): SHADO’s second-in-command.
  • General James Henderson (Grant Taylor): Straker’s superior and president of the International Astrophysical Commission.
  • Colonel Virginia Lake (Wanda Ventham): A SHADO operative who later becomes first officer.
  • Captain Peter Carlin (Peter Gordeno): First commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Nina Barry (Dolores Mantez): Moonbase operative.
  • Captain Lew Waterman (Gary Myers): Second commander of Skydiver.
  • Lieutenant Keith Ford (Keith Alexander): Communications officer.
  • Lieutenant Ayshea Johnson (Ayshea Brough): SHADO headquarters officer.
  • Doctor Douglas Jackson (Vladek Sheybal): SHADO psychiatrist and science officer.
  • Lieutenant Joan Harrington (Antonia Ellis): Moonbase operative.
  • Miss Ealand (Norma Ronald): Straker’s secretary.
  • Lieutenant Mark Bradley (Harry Baird): Interceptor pilot.

Minor characters ðŸ”—

Shakira Baksh (later Michael Caine’s wife) played Joanna, a Moonbase operative. Steven Berkoff played Interceptor pilot Steve Minto, and Georgina Moon played Lieutenant Sylvia Howell.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The 26 episodes were broadcast in a non-chronological order by ITV. The list provides the original ATV (Midlands) broadcast order, along with director, writer, original air date, and production code. Episode titles include “Identified,” “Exposed,” “The Cat with Ten Lives,” “Conflict,” “A Question of Priorities,” and “The Long Sleep.”

Alternative viewing orders ðŸ”—

Different viewing orders exist, including production order, ATV broadcast order, and recommended orders by UFO Series, Fanderson, and ITC. A table compares these different orders.

Production ðŸ”—

Lew Grade approached Gerry Anderson to create a live-action TV series, resulting in UFO. The series was influenced by UFO sightings and Christiaan Barnard’s transplant operations. Sylvia Anderson designed the costumes, including the purple wigs for female Moonbase staff. The Harlington-Straker Studio was the actual studio where the series was filmed.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming began in April 1969 at MGM-British Studios, then moved to Pinewood Studios in June 1970. George Sewell and Gabrielle Drake left after the studio change. Harry Baird and Peter Gordeno also left the series.

Costumes ðŸ”—

Female Moonbase personnel wore purple wigs, silver catsuits, and heavy eye makeup for a futuristic look. Ed Bishop initially bleached his hair, then wore a white wig. Other male characters also wore wigs. Only two alien suits were made.

Special effects ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings supervised the special effects, using techniques like double-walled visors and underwater effects.

Vehicle design ðŸ”—

Derek Meddings and Mike Trim designed the vehicles. The gull-winged cars were originally built for DoppelgÃ¤nger. The blue SHADO Jeeps were built on Mini Moke chassis. Few original props and miniatures have survived.

Broadcast ðŸ”—

Broadcasters were unsure if UFO was for adults or children. In the UK, episodes were shown in the late afternoon and Saturday mornings.

Reception ðŸ”—

Reviews of UFO are mixed. Some praise the visuals, music, and costumes, while others criticize the writing and pacing. Some reviews note the series’ mix of adult themes and science fiction elements.

Aborted second series ðŸ”—

ITC commissioned a second series, UFO 2, set entirely on the Moon. However, when ratings dropped, ITC cancelled the plans. Gerry Anderson then created Space: 1999 from the pre-production work.

Merchandise ðŸ”—

The series generated a range of toys, including Dinky die-cast vehicles.

Compilation films ðŸ”—

Several episodes were compiled into films, including Invasion: UFO. Italian producers also created compilation films with mixed reviews.

Home media ðŸ”—

Channel 5 and ITC released VHS collections. The complete series was released on DVD in 2002.

Proposed feature film ðŸ”—

In 2009, a feature film adaptation was announced, but it did not enter production.

In other media ðŸ”—

Stories set in the UFO universe have appeared in novels, comics, and video games. Julian Gollop cited UFO as an influence for UFO: Enemy Unknown. Yoshiyuki Sadamoto drew inspiration from UFO for character designs in Neon Genesis Evangelion.

Translations ðŸ”—

The series has been translated into French, German, Japanese, Italian, Spanish, and Brazilian Portuguese.

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia article discusses various conspiracy theories surrounding Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), particularly the idea that governments, especially the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life or technology. It also explores the evolution of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: governments concealing evidence of extraterrestrial involvement. It traces the origins of these theories back to pulp science fiction and the “lost continent” myths. The section highlights Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting as a catalyst for widespread UFO reports and the subsequent speculation about secret technologies. Donald Keyhoe is identified as a key figure in popularizing the idea of a government cover-up. The emergence of the “Men in Black” concept is also mentioned. The section further explains how UFO conspiracy theories became more prevalent after the Kennedy assassination, linking his death to aliens. The term “Cosmic Watergate” is introduced to describe the alleged cover-up. The section also mentions the influence of films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind and the introduction of the Roswell incident to a mass audience. The shift from benevolent “space brothers” to malevolent aliens in the 1980s is discussed, along with the connection of UFO cover-ups to alien abductions, cattle mutilations, and the JFK assassination. The section concludes by noting the resurgence of interest in UFO conspiracy theories in the 1990s and 2017 with Leslie Kean’s stories of a Pentagon UFO program.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It mentions government investigations like Project Blue Book and Project Condign, as well as studies by organizations and individuals. The section emphasizes that these investigations have not confirmed claims of extraterrestrial intelligence or other unconventional explanations for UFOs. It highlights that scientists and skeptical organizations offer prosaic explanations, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes. The section also notes that beliefs surrounding UFOs have inspired new religions and that social scientists view the ongoing interest in UFOs as a form of modern folklore and mythology. Benjamin Radford’s argument against the feasibility of a long-term, international UFO cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key individuals who have promoted UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent figures from the 1950s to the 1970s. The section also notes that some proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, had mental health issues, while others, like Gray Barker, Carl Allen, Richard Doty, Bill Moore, and Ray Santelli, confessed to hoaxes or lies. The violent ends of Morris Jessup, James E. McDonald, and Bill Cooper are also mentioned. The section lists individuals who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed, including Barry Goldwater, Lord Hill-Norton, Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, Gordon Cooper, and Edgar Mitchell. 21st-century proponents such as Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the presence of UFO conspiracy theories in popular culture. It mentions films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned as featuring government efforts to conceal information about extraterrestrial beings. John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, where he confesses to a UFO cover-up, is also noted. The Sidney Sheldon novel The Doomsday Conspiracy and the American Horror Story: Double Feature series are also mentioned.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the connection between UFO conspiracy theories and new religious movements. It identifies the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate as examples of religious groups that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology’s view of inhabited planets is also mentioned. Theosophists and occultists, such as Meade Layne, George Adamski, George Hunt Williamson, and Guy Warren Ballard, are discussed as early proponents of extraterrestrial contact. The Nation of Islam’s concept of The Mother Plane is also explored. The section also mentions UFO religions such as Unarius, the Aetherius Society, RaÃ«lism, and the Order of the Solar Temple. The Heaven’s Gate mass suicide, linked to the Hale-Bopp comet, is also discussed.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his hiring of Kenneth Arnold to investigate the Maury Island incident and the magazine’s claims of a cover-up.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses Richard Shaver’s stories of a secret underground race and their spaceships, published in Amazing Stories. It mentions Palmer’s argument that governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent “flying disc craze.” It mentions the Roswell incident and Palmer’s investigation of the Maury Island report.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the aftermath of the 1947 flying disc craze, including Palmer’s linking of the sightings to Shaver’s claims and Shaver’s prediction that the truth about the discs would remain secret. It also mentions Palmer’s later linking of UFOs to the JFK assassination and Watergate.

National Coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s claims of recovered alien bodies from crashed flying saucers and the subsequent exposure of the hoax by True magazine.

Air Force Accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings, including General John Samford’s press conference and the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education. It also mentions Al Chop’s role as a press officer for Project Bluebook and the film Unidentified Flying Objects: The True Story of Flying Saucers.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, involving Carl Meredith Allen’s letters and annotations.

‘Men in Black’ Legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the origin of the “Men in Black” concept in Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increasing government skepticism during the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and the involvement of Fred Crisman, linking UFO conspiracy theories to the Kennedy assassination.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” with J. Allen Hynek’s accusations of a government cover-up.

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the legends of alien bodies stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the emergence of alien abduction reports, starting with the Betty and Barney Hill case and the Travis Walton incident.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection covers Jesse Marcel’s changing statements about the Roswell incident and the increasing attention given to the story by the National Enquirer.

Doty and Lear Promote the “Dark Side” ðŸ”—

This section discusses the shift towards “ufology’s dark side” in the 1980s, with Richard Doty and John Lear promoting theories of government collusion with evil aliens.

This subsection explores the connection between cattle mutilations, UFO sightings, and “quiet helicopters” in the Colorado-New Mexico border region.

item.title: Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise
item.description:
Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise ðŸ”—

This article provides a comprehensive list of alien races featured in the Star Trek franchise, spanning from the original series to the latest installments. It emphasizes the significance of these alien encounters as a core element of the Star Trek narrative.

Key ðŸ”—

This section provides a key to the abbreviations used throughout the list to indicate the specific Star Trek media (TV series, films) in which each alien race appears. It includes the title, date, and medium for each abbreviation.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

  • Aenar: A sub-species of Andorians from the planet Andoria, characterized by their light blue/white skin, near-blindness, and telepathic abilities. They are generally pacifistic. Key figures include Hemmer from Strange New Worlds and Talla, Shran’s daughter.
  • Andorian: A blue-skinned, antenna-bearing humanoid species from Andoria. They are depicted as a warrior race and were founding members of the United Federation of Planets.
  • Angosian: A species known for genetically and chemically engineering soldiers for the Tarsian Wars. These “super soldiers” were later confined to a penal settlement.
  • Antedean: An ichthyohumanoid species from Antede III that resembles fish and has a strong aversion to space travel.
  • Arcadian: A member of the United Federation of Planets with a representative on the Federation Council. They have large, round heads and distinctive hairstyles.
  • Arcturian: A species known for their clones, which have a melted skin appearance. They hail from the densely populated world Arcturus.
  • Axanar: The first extraterrestrial race befriended by Earth people aboard the NX-01 Enterprise. Captain Garth of Izar achieved a great victory on behalf of the Federation at the Battle of Axanar.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

  • Bajoran: A humanoid species from the planet Bajor, characterized by nose ridges and deep spirituality. They worship The Prophets and were occupied by the Cardassians. Key locations include Bajor.
  • Ba’ku: A technologically advanced humanoid civilization that chose to abandon technology and live a simple life on an isolated planet with metaphasic radiation. Their aging process is significantly slowed. Key locations include The Briar Patch.
  • Benzite: A humanoid race from the planet Benzar, a member of the United Federation of Planets. They are known for their resistance to poisons and ability to digest almost any organic compound.
  • Betazoid: A telepathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed, a member of the United Federation of Planets. Deanna Troi is a prominent half-Betazoid character.
  • Bolian: Humanoids with blue skin and a ridge running from the back of their heads to their noses. They are active members of the Federation and known for crystal steel and the Bank of Bolius.
  • Borg: A pseudo-species of cybernetically enhanced individuals forming a collective consciousness. They assimilate other species to achieve perfection.
  • Breen: A mysterious race who joined the Dominion during the Dominion War.
  • Brikar: A large, rock-like species. Rok-Tahk from Star Trek: Prodigy is a notable example.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

  • Cardassian: A species with ridges along their foreheads and necks, known for their military dictatorship and conflict with the United Federation of Planets. Key figures include Garak and Gul Dukat. Their homeworld is Cardassia Prime.
  • Chameloid: A race of shapeshifters. Martia is a notable example encountered by Kirk and McCoy.
  • Changeling: A race of fluid shapeshifters who founded the Dominion. Odo is a prominent Changeling character.

D ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “D.”

  • Douwd: Immortal energy beings with vast powers. Only one is known to exist, who committed xenocide against the Husnock.
  • Deltan: A humanoid species from the planet Delta IV, known for their strong sexual attraction. They take a vow of chastity upon joining Starfleet. Ilia and Melle are notable Deltans.

E ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “E.”

  • Edosian: A race of sentient tripedal beings. Lieutenant Arex was introduced in Star Trek: The Animated Series.
  • El-Aurian: A humanoid race known as “Listeners,” with long lifespans and a patient, wise demeanor. Their homeworld, El-Auria, was destroyed by the Borg. Guinan is a notable El-Aurian.

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “F.”

  • Kelpien: A species from the planet Kaminar, suppressed by the Ba’ul for generations. Commander Saru is a notable Kelpien.

item.title: Roswell (film)
item.description:
Roswell (film) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1994 American science fiction television film Roswell, also known as Roswell: The U.F.O. Cover-Up. The film is based on the alleged Roswell UFO incident, which involves the U.S. military’s supposed capture of a flying saucer and its alien crew after a crash near Roswell, New Mexico, in July 1947. The film also references other UFOlogy events, including Area 51, alien autopsies, the death of James Forrestal, and Majestic-12.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot unfolds through flashbacks at a 30-year reunion of the 509th Operations Group. It centers on Major Jesse Marcel’s investigation into strange debris found on a rancher’s field in July 1947. Despite being told by his superiors that it was merely a downed weather balloon, Marcel persists in his search for the truth, ultimately uncovering the reality of what occurred. Key figures include Major Jesse Marcel and the setting is Roswell, New Mexico.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times. The New York Times praised the film’s tense drama but questioned the plausibility of a long-term cover-up. Variety called it a gripping fictional account and highlighted the convincing pacing and unflinching portrayal of military mendacity. The Los Angeles Times viewed the film as more than just a sci-fi story, focusing on the protagonist’s search for truth.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Kyle MacLachlan as Jesse A. Marcel, Martin Sheen as Townsend, and Dwight Yoakam as Mac Brazel. Other notable cast members include Xander Berkeley, Bob Gunton, Kim Greist, Peter MacNicol, John M. Jackson, and Nick Searcy. The cast also features appearances by Charles Hallahan, Ray McKinnon, Eugene Roche, and Charles Martin Smith.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the citations used in the article, including reviews from The New York Times, Variety, and The Los Angeles Times.

This entry describes the 2005 American science fiction TV film Alien Apocalypse.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot summary details the events of the film:

  • Astronaut Dr. Ivan Hood (Bruce Campbell) and his companion Kelly return to Earth after a 40-year space mission.
  • They discover Earth has been conquered by giant termite-like aliens who used EMP bombs to disable the planet 20 years prior.
  • Humans are enslaved and forced to work in camps.
  • Dr. Hood and Kelly are captured near the ruins of Portland, Oregon.
  • They plan an escape after learning of a surviving President.
  • Kelly is recaptured, and Dr. Hood seeks out the President, eventually finding him a broken man.
  • Dr. Hood rallies escaped slaves to attack the alien camp and rescue Kelly.
  • The attack is successful with the help of the President’s forces.
  • Dr. Hood becomes known as “The Great Exterminator” and continues to fight the aliens.

This entry details the 2004 American science fiction horror television film Alien Lockdown, directed by Tim Cox. It also goes by the names Creature and Predatorman.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a brief introduction to the film, highlighting its genre as science fiction horror and its alternative titles. It names Tim Cox as the director and Ross Helford and T.M. Van Ostrand as the screenwriters, based on a story by John Thompson, Boaz Davidson, and Kenneth M. Badish. The lead actors, John Savage, James Marshall, and Michelle Goh, are also mentioned.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around an ancient alien life force that awakens and threatens humanity. A SWAT team, led by a skilled assassin, must prevent the alien from consuming humans. The alien had been dormant for centuries, waiting for human knowledge to advance enough to unlock its potential. A mad scientist unlocks the genetic code, leading to the creation of mutant creatures. item.title: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film)
item.description:
E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (1982 film) ðŸ”—

A comprehensive overview of the 1982 American science fiction film produced and directed by Steven Spielberg and written by Melissa Mathison. The film tells the story of a boy, Elliott, who befriends an extraterrestrial stranded on Earth.

Plot ðŸ”—

A race of alien botanists visits Earth, but one of them gets separated from the group and is left behind. The alien takes shelter in a shed belonging to the family of ten-year-old Elliott Taylor. Elliott lures the alien back to his home with Reese’s Pieces, and he hides the creature in his room. Elliott introduces E.T. to his older brother, Michael, and five-year-old sister Gertie, who agree to keep E.T. hidden from their mother, Mary. Elliott and the creature begin to bond, they start to share thoughts and emotions. E.T. displays telekinetic abilities and revives a dead chrysanthemum.

At school, Elliott becomes intoxicated because E.T. is drinking beer and watching television at home. Inspired by a Buck Rogers comic strip, E.T. builds a makeshift device to “phone home”, using various parts around the Taylor home. On Halloween, the children disguise E.T. as a ghost and Elliott sneaks E.T. into the forest, where they set up the device to call E.T.’s people. Elliott begs E.T. to stay on Earth with him, before falling asleep and waking alone in the forest the next day. He returns home to his worried family, while Michael searches for E.T., finding him pale and weakened in a culvert. He takes E.T. home, where Elliott is also growing weaker, and reveal the creature to Mary just before government agents invade and quarantine the house. The lead agent, Keys, asks for Elliott’s help to save E.T., stating that meeting aliens was his childhood dream and he considers E.T’s arrival a genuine miracle. However, E.T. dies while Elliott rapidly recovers. Left alone to say goodbye, Elliott tells E.T. that he loves him, but E.T.’s heart begins to glow and he is revived and restored to health. E.T. tells Elliott that his people are returning for him.

Elliott and Michael flee with E.T. on their bikes, flanked by Michael’s friends who help them evade the pursuing authorities. Heading towards a roadblock, E.T. levitates the boys to safety and lands them in the forest. E.T.’s ship arrives, and he says goodbye to Michael and Gertie, who gifts him the chrysanthemum he previously revived. Elliott tearfully asks E.T. to stay, but E.T. places his glowing finger on Elliott’s head and tells him that he will always be there. The children, Mary, and Keys observe as the ship blasts off into space, leaving a rainbow in the sky.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

  • Dee Wallace as Mary Taylor, the single mother.
  • Henry Thomas as Elliott Taylor, the boy who befriends E.T.
  • Peter Coyote as Keys, the government agent.
  • Robert MacNaughton as Michael Taylor, Elliott’s older brother.
  • Drew Barrymore as Gertie Taylor, Elliott’s younger sister.

Other cast members include K.C. Martel, Sean Frye, C. Thomas Howell, Erika Eleniak, David O’Dell, Richard Swingler, Frank Toth, Robert Barton, Michael Darrell, and Pat Welsh as the voice of E.T.

Production ðŸ”—

Details the development, pre-production, casting, filming, and music of the movie.

Development ðŸ”—

The film’s concept originated from an imaginary friend Steven Spielberg created after his parents’ divorce. He initially planned a darker project called Night Skies but developed a subplot into what became E.T. Melissa Mathison wrote the first draft, titled E.T. and Me.

Pre-production ðŸ”—

Carlo Rambaldi designed the animatronics for E.T., inspired by his painting Women of Delta and the faces of Carl Sandburg, Albert Einstein, and Ernest Hemingway. Kathleen Kennedy visited the Jules Stein Eye Institute to study eyes for E.T. Four heads were created for filming, one as the main animatronic and the others for facial expressions, as well as a costume. Tamara De Treaux, Pat Bilon, and Matthew DeMeritt took turns wearing the costume. Mars, Incorporated refused to allow M&M’s to be used in the film, so The Hershey Company was asked if Reese’s Pieces could be used, and it agreed. Henry Feinberg created E.T.’s communicator device.

Casting ðŸ”—

Spielberg cast Henry Thomas as Elliott after an impressive improvised audition scene. Robert MacNaughton played Michael, and Drew Barrymore was cast as Gertie. Pat Welsh provided the major voice work for E.T., with additional sounds from Debra Winger, Spielberg, and various animals. A scene featuring Harrison Ford as the school principal was cut.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography began on September 8, 1981, in Los Angeles County and the San Fernando Valley, under the cover name A Boy’s Life. Filming locations included Culver City High School, Northridge, Tujunga, Laird International Studios in Culver City, and a redwood forest near Crescent City in Northern California. The exterior Halloween scene and the “flying bicycle” chase scenes were filmed in Porter Ranch. The film was shot in roughly chronological order to achieve convincing emotional performances from the young cast. Sean Frye revealed how the visual effect close-up shots for the climax of the “flying bicycle” chase scene were filmed. BMX riders Robert Cardoza, Greg Maes, and David Lee served as stunt doubles for the scene.

Music ðŸ”—

John Williams composed the score, taking a modernist approach with polytonality and the Lydian mode. Spielberg edited the final chase sequence to suit Williams’ music.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of divorce, alienation, growing up, and communication. Critics have noted parallels between E.T. and Elliott, as well as religious parallels between E.T. and Jesus. Some see the movie as a modern fairy tale, drawing comparisons to Peter Pan and The Wizard of Oz. Kathleen Kennedy highlighted tolerance as an important theme.

Reception ðŸ”—

Details the film’s release, sales, critical response, and accolades.

Release and sales ðŸ”—

E.T. premiered at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival and was released in the United States on June 11, 1982. It opened at number one at the US box office and stayed at the top for six weeks. In 1983, E.T. surpassed Star Wars to become the highest-grossing film of all time. The film was also a merchandising success, with dolls selling 15 million units by September 1982 and becoming the best-selling toy that Christmas season. The film was re-released in 1985 and 2002, earning another $60 million and $68 million respectively. It was re-released in IMAX on August 12, 2022, to commemorate the film’s 40th anniversary.

Home media ðŸ”—

E.T. was released on VHS and LaserDisc on October 27, 1988. The videos were priced with a recommended retail price of $24.95, the lowest initial price at the time for a major movie compared to the normal price of $89.95. The film doubled the record pre-orders of Cinderella released the same month and went on to sell over 15 million VHS units in the United States, and grossed over $250 million in video sales revenue.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The film received near-universal acclaim. Roger Ebert gave it four out of four stars, and Michael Sragow of Rolling Stone called Spielberg “a space age Jean Renoir.” George Will was one of few to pan the film. The film holds a 99% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film was nominated for nine Oscars at the 55th Academy Awards, winning four: Best Original Score, Best Sound, Best Sound Effects Editing, and Best Visual Effects. It also won Golden Globe Awards for Best Picture (Drama) and Best Original Score.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The film has been voted one of the greatest films of all time by the American Film Institute. The line “E.T. phone home” was ranked 15th on AFI’s 100 Years…100 Movie Quotes list. In 1994, it was selected for preservation in the U.S. National Film Registry. In 2023, actress Rita Moreno named E.T. as one of her top five favorite films. Many people in the world of entertainment have cited E.T. as among their favorite films, including filmmakers Stanley Kubrick, Sidney Lumet, Edgar Wright, J. A. Bayona, Dustin Lance Black, Spenser Cohen, Dustin Guy Defa, Gareth Edwards, Michael Giacchino, Sarah Greenwood, Chad Hartigan, Max Hechtman, Jordan Horowitz, Phil Joanou, Travis Knight, David Lowery, Rod Roddenberry, CÃ©line Sciamma, Ed Solomon, Goran Stolevski, Clement Virgo and Molly Manning Walker, actors

item.title: Contact (1997 film)
item.description:
Contact (1997 film) ðŸ”—

Contact is a 1997 American science fiction drama film directed by Robert Zemeckis, based on Carl Sagan’s 1985 novel of the same name. The film stars Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor Arroway, a SETI scientist who discovers evidence of extraterrestrial life and is chosen to make first contact.

Plot ðŸ”—

Dr. Ellie Arroway, driven by the childhood loss of her father and inspired by his encouragement of her amateur radio hobby, dedicates her life to SETI research at the Arecibo Observatory. Facing funding cuts led by President’s science advisor David Drumlin, she secures private funding from the reclusive billionaire S.R. Hadden to continue her work at the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico.

Four years later, Arroway discovers a signal from the star Vega containing a sequence of prime numbers. The discovery leads to a global effort to decode the message, which is complicated by Drumlin and the National Security Council’s attempts to control the facility. The signal is found to contain a video of Adolf Hitler’s opening address at the 1936 Summer Olympics, the first Earth transmission strong enough to reach Vega.

Arroway’s team decodes the signal, revealing schematics for a complex machine designed to transport a single person. Multiple nations collaborate to fund the machine’s construction at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral. An international panel is formed to select a candidate for the journey. Arroway is a leading contender, but her atheism, highlighted by panel member Palmer Joss, jeopardizes her selection. Drumlin is chosen, but a religious terrorist destroys the machine during testing, killing Drumlin and others.

Hadden, now terminally ill and living on the Mir space station, informs Arroway of a second, secretly constructed machine in Hokkaido, Japan. Arroway is selected to use it. Equipped with recording devices, she enters the pod and travels through wormholes, observing alien structures and a celestial event. She finds herself on a beach resembling a childhood drawing of Pensacola, Florida, and encounters an alien taking the form of her deceased father, who explains that the aliens have been monitoring humanity’s radio emissions and have deemed them ready for first contact.

Arroway awakens in the pod, which has only fallen a short distance into a safety net. Mission control insists that the experiment achieved nothing, and her recording devices show only static. A Congressional Committee, led by Michael Kitz, investigates the possibility of a hoax orchestrated by Hadden, who has since died. Arroway asks the committee to accept her testimony on faith, emphasizing the profound impact of her experience. Kitz and Rachel Constantine, a White House official, acknowledge that Arroway’s device recorded 18 hours of static. Arroway receives continued funding for SETI research at the VLA.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film features a cast of notable actors:

  • Jodie Foster as Dr. Eleanor “Ellie” Ann Arroway
  • Jena Malone as young Ellie
  • Matthew McConaughey as Palmer Joss
  • David Morse as Theodore Arroway
  • Tom Skerritt as Dr. David Drumlin
  • James Woods as Michael Kitz
  • John Hurt as S. R. Hadden
  • William Fichtner as Kent Clarke
  • Angela Bassett as Rachel Constantine
  • Jake Busey as Joseph
  • Rob Lowe as Richard Rank
  • Geoffrey Blake as Fisher
  • Max Martini as Willie
  • Steven Ford as Major John Russell
  • Jay Leno as himself
  • Larry King as himself
  • Ann Druyan as herself

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan conceived Contact in 1979 with Lynda Obst and Peter Guber at Casablanca FilmWorks. Sagan and Ann Druyan completed the film treatment in 1980, aiming to depict a realistic first contact scenario. Kip Thorne consulted on wormhole travel. The character of Ellie Arroway was not directly inspired by Jill Tarter, though Foster met her for research. The name Ellie was inspired by Eleanor Roosevelt.

The project faced numerous rewrites and stalled development. Sagan rewrote Contact as a novel, published in 1985. Roland JoffÃ© and George Miller were initially attached to direct but later departed.

Filming ðŸ”—

Robert Zemeckis took over as director, securing artistic control. Filming began in September 1996 and concluded in February 1997. Key locations included the Very Large Array (VLA) in New Mexico, Warner Hollywood Studios, and Culver Studios. CNN news personalities were scripted into the film to enhance realism. Second unit filming took place at the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico, Fiji, Saint John, US Virgin Islands, and Newfoundland, Canada. Technical consultants from the SETI Institute, Caltech, and a former White House staff member were involved. Sagan participated in the production until his death in December 1996, and the film is dedicated to him.

Visual effects ðŸ”—

Eight VFX companies, including Sony Pictures Imageworks, Weta Digital, and Industrial Light & Magic, collaborated on the visual effects. Weta Digital designed the wormhole sequence. Digital alterations were made to news footage of Bill Clinton. Digital color correction addressed continuity issues during location shooting. The opening scene is a five-minute CGI sequence depicting a zoom out from Earth to the distant universe. The mirror shot was created through three different plates and manipulated in CGI. The machine was designed by concept artist Steve Burg, reusing a design he created as a “time-displacement device” for an unused scene in Terminator 2.

Music ðŸ”—

Alan Silvestri composed and conducted the original score. A soundtrack album was released in August 1997.

Themes ðŸ”—

Contact explores the cultural conflicts between religion and science, particularly concerning the existence of God. The film presents various viewpoints on faith and scientific evidence. It depicts intense public debate about the implications of alien contact, including questions about morality and the role of science. The film raises questions about the authenticity of Arroway’s journey, leaving room for doubt. The film suggests that science and religion can coexist.

Release ðŸ”—

Contact’s release in July 1997 boosted interest in Sagan’s novel. The book appeared on The New York Times Best Seller list. The film premiered on July 1, 1997, and was released in the United States and Canada on July 11, 1997.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

The film received generally positive reviews. Critics praised its exploration of scientific and theological concepts but noted weaknesses in storytelling.

Awards ðŸ”—

Contact won the Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation and two Saturn Awards. It received nominations for an Academy Award for Best Sound and a Golden Globe Award for Best Lead Actress in a Motion Picture â€“ Drama (Jodie Foster).

Reactions ðŸ”—

Bill Clinton ðŸ”—

The film used digitally altered footage of President Bill Clinton, leading to a protest from the White House.

CNN ðŸ”—

CNN chairman Tom Johnson expressed regret over allowing CNN staff to appear in the film, citing concerns about blurring the lines between news and entertainment.

NASA ðŸ”—

The scene involving a cyanide pill caused controversy, with conflicting accounts from NASA advisor Gerald D. Griffin and Carl Sagan.

SETI ðŸ”—

SETI.org published a review of the film, highlighting its accuracy in depicting SETI research.

Lawsuits ðŸ”—

Director George Miller unsuccessfully sued Warner Bros. over breach of contract policies. Francis Ford Coppola sued Warner Bros. and Sagan, claiming that Sagan’s novel was based on a story they had developed together. Coppola’s claim was dismissed.

item.title: Alienoid (2022 film)
item.description:
Alienoid (2022 film) ðŸ”—

A 2022 South Korean science fiction action film directed by Choi Dong-hoon, starring Ryu Jun-yeol, Kim Woo-bin, and Kim Tae-ri. The film involves time travel between the Goryeo era and the present day, with the appearance of aliens. It was released in IMAX and 4DX formats. A sequel, Alienoid: Return to the Future, was released in 2024.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot alternates between the modern day and the Goryeo era.

Prologue: 1380 A.D. ðŸ”—

Monk warriors fail to defeat an alien and its human host. Guard and Thunder, humanoid robots from the future, extract the alien. The dying host asks Guard to care for her baby, but Guard initially refuses due to non-interference policies. Thunder smuggles the infant back with them to the modern day.

Timeline 1: 2012-2022 A.D. ðŸ”—

Guard raises the baby girl, Yi-an, without revealing his true identity. Yi-an becomes suspicious and discovers the truth about Guard, Thunder, and her origins.

Yi-an finds her way to Jisan Hospital, the site of an incoming alien prisoner transport. Guard and Thunder explain alien imprisonment mechanics. A prisoner-aligned alien ship arrives, planning to awaken the Controller and release haava to transform Earth’s atmosphere, awakening all alien prisoners and poisoning humanity. The pilot awakens the Controller and releases haava, devastating the city and awakening other prisoners.

Guard, Thunder, and Yi-an kill the alien pilot and prevent further haava release. Badly wounded, Yi-an travels back in time with the aliens, intending to strand them in the past. Guard is destroyed, Thunder sinks in a river, and the Controller is forced to abandon its host.

Timeline 2: 1391 A.D. ðŸ”—

Ten years after Thunder crash-lands, a Taoist bounty hunter named Mureuk pursues the Divine Blade (Guard’s power source). Mureuk meets martial arts figures like the Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd. He also meets Yi-an (the “Girl Who Shoots Thunder”) and Suiter and Ja-jang, aliens from the future who have taken over a local cult. The Divine Blade and Thunder’s location are key to controlling the haava release.

A chaotic battle ensues. Yi-an lures one alien away, while the other is defeated. Yi-an approaches Thunder’s location.

Monk Guru, the Dual Mages, and Dogturd were all near the initial alien crash and are potential hosts for the Controller. However, Mureuk, Monk Guru’s apprentice, rescued Yi-an and became the Controller’s new host, losing his memories.

Cast ðŸ”—

  • Ryu Jun-yeol as Mureuk, a Taoist bounty hunter.
  • Kim Woo-bin as Guard and Thunder, supernatural beings.
  • Kim Tae-ri as Yi-an, a woman who shoots thunder.
  • So Ji-sub as Moon Do-seok, a detective.
  • Yum Jung-ah as Heug-seol, a mage.
  • Jo Woo-jin as Cheong-woon, a mage.
  • Kim Eui-sung as Ja-jang, a masked man.
  • Lee Hanee as Min Gae-in, a curious woman.
  • Shin Jung-geun as Right King, a follower of Mureuk.
  • Lee Si-hoon as Left King, a follower of Mureuk.
  • Ji Kun-woo as Suiter, a man in a modern suit.
  • Kim Dae-myung as the voice of Thunder.
  • Shim Dal-gi as a bride replaced by Yi-an.
  • Yoon Byung-hee as a shaman.
  • Kim Ki-cheon as Dogturd, a man who knows the location of the divine sword.
  • Yoon Kyung-ho as a patient at Jisan Hospital.
  • Ok Ja-yeon as a doctor at Jisan Hospital.
  • Lee Seon-hee as an inn owner.
  • Yoo Jae-myung as Hyun-gam.
  • Kim Hae-sook as an old woman in Goryeo.
  • Jeon Yeo-been as Hong Eon-nyeon, a woman with an alien prisoner.

Production ðŸ”—

Filming took place over 13 months, with both parts filmed simultaneously. Choi Dong-hoon spent two and a half years writing the script. Jang Young-gyu and Kim Tae-kyung were in charge of music and cinematography, respectively. Yoo Sang-seop and Ryu Seong-cheol served as martial arts directors. Ryu Seong-hee and Lee Ha-jun were the art directors. Dexter Studio handled the CG. Filming locations included Andong, North Gyeongsang Province. The production cost for both parts was estimated at 40 billion won.

Release ðŸ”—

Alienoid was released on July 20, 2022, in South Korea in IMAX and 4DX formats by CJ E&M. Well Go USA acquired North American distribution rights. It was the closing film at the 21st New York Asian Film Festival and screened at the 26th Fantasia International Film Festival. It became available for streaming on Netflix from December 28, 2022.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received mixed reviews from South Korean critics, with some praising its unique worldview and others criticizing its confusing characters and lore. It was compared to Choi Dong-hoon’s previous film, Jeon Woo-chi: The Taoist Wizard. The film was a box-office failure, requiring 7 million admissions to break even.

Sequel ðŸ”—

Alienoid: Return to the Future was released in January 2024.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film received nominations for several awards, including:

  • Baeksang Arts Awards: Yum Jung-ah nominated for Best Supporting Actress â€“ Film
  • Blue Dragon Film Awards: Nominated for Technical Award
  • Buil Film Awards: Yum Jung-ah nominated for Best Supporting Actress, also nominated for Best Music
  • Chunsa Film Art Awards: Nominated for Technical Award (VFX)
  • Director’s Cut Awards: Choi Dong-hoon nominated for Best Director in film
  • Grand Bell Awards: Won Best Art Direction and Best Visual Effects, also nominated for Best Film Editing, Best Costume Design, and Best Music

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and large, black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the image of Grey aliens.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoids with grey skin, elongated bodies, small chests, and a lack of muscular definition. They are said to lack external human body parts like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their most striking feature is their disproportionately large heads with no hair and large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance ðŸ”—

This subsection further elaborates on the physical appearance of Grey aliens. They are generally depicted as lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. The most prominent feature is their large, black, almond-shaped eyes, often described as lacking eye whites. They are also frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the origin of the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association began with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and determined that the aliens’ home was Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. It notes that descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate alien encounter claims, citing H.G. Wells’ descriptions of future humans in “The Man of the Year Million” (1893) and the Eloi in “The Time Machine” (1895).

Origins ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien concept. H.G. Wells’ depictions of future humans and the Eloi are mentioned as early examples of beings with Grey-like characteristics. Aleister Crowley’s 1917 encounter with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, described as similar to a modern Grey, is also discussed. Gustav Sandgren’s 1933 science fiction novel, Den okÃ¤nda faran (The Unknown Danger), which describes a race of extraterrestrials with grey skin, bald heads, and large eyes, is identified as a key influence on the modern image of Grey aliens.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. The Hills claimed that in 1961, they were abducted by grayish-skinned humanoid beings and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer’s 1990 article suggests that Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which featured an alien with large eyes. Carl Sagan echoed these suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses how Grey aliens became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hill’s encounter. Journalist C.D.B. Bryan notes that 73% of reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. The section also mentions the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, and claims that individuals saw the U.S. military handling child-sized beings with oversized heads and slanted eyes. Whitley Strieber’s 1987 book Communion, which described his alleged encounters with Greys, is also discussed. Jimmy Guieu’s 1988 interview on TF1’s Ciel, mon mardi! introduced the term “the little greys” to the French public.

The section further notes that Greys have become the subject of many conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of a government disinformation campaign or a product of mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli’s 1995 film Alien Autopsy, which claimed to depict the autopsy of a “real” Grey, is also mentioned.

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section examines various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

This subsection analyzes the role of Greys in alien abduction claims. It notes that Greys make up a significant percentage of reported alien encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focus of abduction claims, with abductees reporting that the Greys stare into their eyes during mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses Frederick V. Malmstrom’s “Mother Hypothesis,” which suggests that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom argues that the face of a Grey can be reconstructed through transformation of a mother’s face based on early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

This subsection briefly mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section explores the depiction of Grey aliens in popular culture. It notes that Greys have become a common way to depict extraterrestrials in fiction, supplanting the “little green men” archetype. Examples include Ultraman (1966), Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977), Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. The section also mentions the increasing association of Greys with conspiracy theories in the 1990s, citing The X-Files as a prominent example. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The films Paul (2011) and Dark Skies (2013) are also mentioned, as well as the TV series Resident Alien (2021) and the game Greyhill Incident (2023).

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin, lacking external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition, and having disproportionately short legs. A key feature is their large heads relative to their bodies, devoid of hair, with small orifices for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their eyes are large, opaque, black, and almond-shaped. They are often described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

The connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system stems from Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the map showed the aliens’ home system. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and identified the stars as Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype.

Origins ðŸ”—

Descriptions of beings resembling Grey aliens predate reported encounters. H.G. Wells described future humans with similar features in his 1893 article “The Man of the Year Million” and his 1895 novel The Time Machine. In 1917, Aleister Crowley described an entity named Lam with a similar appearance. In 1933, Swedish novelist Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described aliens with grey clothes, bald heads, and large eyes in his science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 brought the Grey alien archetype to public attention in 1965. The Hills claimed they were abducted by grey-skinned humanoids and taken aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested Barney’s memories, revealed under hypnosis, may have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which aired shortly before Barney’s first hypnotic session. Carl Sagan also suggested Invaders from Mars as a potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

Following the Hill’s encounter, Greys became a central figure in ufology and extraterrestrial folklore, particularly in the United States, where they account for 73% of reported alien encounters. The alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947, was later linked to Greys. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published Communion, a book detailing his alleged encounters with Greys, which became a bestseller and was adapted into a film. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu introduced the term “les Petits-Gris” (little greys) to French audiences.

Greys have become the subject of conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of government disinformation campaigns or mind-control experiments. Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage of an autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from Roswell, but later admitted it was a “reconstruction.”

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

Greys are frequently associated with alien abduction claims, accounting for a significant percentage of reported encounters in various countries. Abduction claims are often described as traumatic, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes of the Greys are often a focal point, with claims of inducing hallucinogenic states or emotions through staring.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

Neurologist Steven Novella suggests that Grey aliens are a product of the human imagination, with their features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

Frederick V. Malmstrom proposes that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development, reconstructing the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

Biologist Jack Cohen argues that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

The interdimensional, cryptoterrestrial, and time-traveler hypotheses offer alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of these alleged beings.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section highlights the presence of Grey aliens in various forms of media.

Grey aliens have become a common depiction of extraterrestrials in fiction, replacing the earlier “little green men.” They have appeared in films and television shows such as Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, and Stargate. During the 1990s, plotlines linking Greys to conspiracy theories became prevalent, as seen in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The film Paul features a Grey alien who attributes the Greys’ presence in pop culture to government manipulation. The film Dark Skies features child abduction by Greys. Greys also appear in the TV series Resident Alien and the game Greyhill Incident.

item.title: Alien (film)
item.description:
Alien (film) ðŸ”—

Alien is a 1979 science fiction horror film directed by Ridley Scott and written by Dan O’Bannon. The film follows the crew of the commercial spaceship Nostromo as they encounter a deadly extraterrestrial creature. The film stars Tom Skerritt, Sigourney Weaver, Veronica Cartwright, Harry Dean Stanton, John Hurt, Ian Holm, and Yaphet Kotto.

Plot ðŸ”—

The commercial spaceship Nostromo is returning to Earth when its computer detects a transmission from a nearby planetoid. The crew investigates a derelict alien spaceship and discovers a chamber containing hundreds of eggs. One of the crew members, Kane, is attacked by a creature that attaches itself to his face. The creature eventually detaches itself, and Kane appears to be fine. However, during a meal, a small alien creature bursts from his chest, killing him. The crew then tries to hunt down and kill the alien, which grows into a deadly creature. The crew members are killed off one by one, until only Ripley remains. She initiates the ship’s self-destruct sequence and escapes in a shuttle, but the alien stows away. Ripley manages to blast the alien into space before putting herself into stasis for the return to Earth.

Cast ðŸ”—

  • Tom Skerritt as Dallas, captain of the Nostromo.
  • Sigourney Weaver as Ripley, the warrant officer.
  • Veronica Cartwright as Lambert, the navigator.
  • Harry Dean Stanton as Brett, the engineering technician.
  • John Hurt as Kane, the executive officer.
  • Ian Holm as Ash, the science officer who is revealed to be an android.
  • Yaphet Kotto as Parker, the chief engineer.
  • Bolaji Badejo as the alien.
  • Helen Horton as the voice of Mother, the Nostromo’s computer.

Production ðŸ”—

Writing ðŸ”—

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the screenplay, with O’Bannon initially writing 29 pages titled Memory. The story was influenced by various science fiction and horror works, including The Thing from Another World, Forbidden Planet, and Planet of the Vampires. The script was pitched as “Jaws in space”. Hill and Giler made revisions to the script, adding the android character Ash.

Development ðŸ”—

20th Century-Fox greenlit Alien after the success of Star Wars. Ridley Scott was chosen as the director. Scott created detailed storyboards, which led to the film’s budget being doubled.

Casting ðŸ”—

Casting calls were held in New York City and London. Scott wanted strong actors to focus on the film’s visual style. The crew of the Nostromo was intended to resemble working astronauts, described as “truckers in space”. Scott wrote backstories for each character.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming took place at Pinewood Studios and Shepperton Studios near London, and model filming was done at Bray Studios. The production schedule was short due to the film’s low budget. Sets were constructed for the alien planetoid, the Nostromo, and the derelict spacecraft. The space suits were thick and bulky, causing discomfort for the actors.

Post-production ðŸ”—

Editing and post-production took roughly 20 weeks. The film was edited to have a slow pace to build suspense. One scene that was cut involved Ripley encountering Dallas and Brett, who had been partially cocooned by the alien.

Music ðŸ”—

Jerry Goldsmith composed the musical score. Scott initially wanted Isao Tomita, but Fox wanted a more familiar composer. Goldsmith’s score was nominated for a Golden Globe Award and a Grammy Award, and it won a BAFTA Award.

Design ðŸ”—

Creature effects ðŸ”—

H. R. Giger designed the alien and its environment. The “facehugger” was the first creature Giger designed. The “chestburster” design was inspired by Francis Bacon’s painting Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion.

The alien ðŸ”—

Giger made conceptual paintings of the adult alien before settling on the final version. Carlo Rambaldi manufactured the head. Bolaji Badejo portrayed the alien in most scenes. Scott chose not to show the full alien for most of the film to create a sense of terror.

Sets ðŸ”—

The sets of the Nostromo’s three decks were created in one piece. Ron Cobb created industrial-style symbols and color-coded signs. The company that owns the Nostromo is referred to as “Weylan-Yutani”. Art director Roger Christian used scrap metal and parts to create set pieces and props.

Spaceships and planets ðŸ”—

Ron Cobb and Chris Foss worked on designs for the spaceship and space suits. Cobb created sketches of the ship’s interiors and exteriors. The spaceships and planets were shot using models and miniatures.

Title sequence ðŸ”—

The title sequence was developed by R/Greenberg Associates.

Release ðŸ”—

Alien was rated “R” in the United States and “X” in the United Kingdom. It opened in a limited release in American theaters on May 25, 1979, and received a wide release on June 22.

Box office ðŸ”—

The film was a commercial success, grossing $78.9 million in the United States and Â£7,886,000 in the United Kingdom during its first run. Its total worldwide gross has been estimated at between $104.9 million and $203.6 million.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

Critical reaction to Alien was initially mixed. However, in subsequent years, it was critically reassessed and is now considered one of the greatest science fiction and horror films of all time.

Accolades ðŸ”—

Alien won the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects and Saturn Awards for Best Science Fiction Film, Best Direction for Ridley Scott, and Best Supporting Actress for Veronica Cartwright.

Post-release ðŸ”—

Home video ðŸ”—

Alien has been released in many home video formats over the years, including VHS, LaserDisc, and DVD.

Director’s Cut ðŸ”—

In 2003, 20th Century Fox released a “Director’s Cut” of Alien, which included restored footage and recut scenes.

Cinematic analysis ðŸ”—

Critics have analyzed Alien’s sexual overtones and its use of abjection. The film has been interpreted as a metaphor for male fear of penetration and as a representation of the “monstrous-feminine”.

Audience research ðŸ”—

Findings from an international audience research project were published in 2016 as Alien Audiences: Remembering and Evaluating a Classic Movie.

Re-release ðŸ”—

For its 45th anniversary, Alien was re-released in theaters on April 26, 2024.

Legacy ðŸ”—

Critical reassessment ðŸ”—

Despite initial mixed reviews, Alien has received critical acclaim over the years and is seen as one of the most influential science-fiction films.

Cultural influences ðŸ”—

Alien had both an immediate and long-term impact on the science fiction and horror genres. The “chestburster” effect was parodied in Mel Brooks’s comedy Spaceballs. Nintendo’s Metroid video game series was significantly influenced by Alien.

Merchandise ðŸ”—

Alan Dean Foster wrote a novelization of the film. Heavy Metal magazine published a graphic novel adaptation. Model kits and action figures of the alien were released.

School play adaptation ðŸ”—

In 2019, students at North Bergen High School adapted the film into a play, which gained social media recognition and praise from Ridley Scott and Sigourney Weaver.

Video game adaptation ðŸ”—

Two downloadable content packs for the video game Alien: Isolation depict alternate versions of key events from the film, with the original cast members reprising their roles.

Sequels and franchise ðŸ”—

The success of Alien led to three direct sequels: Aliens (1986), Alien 3 (1992), and Alien Resurrection (1997). The story of Ripley’s encounters with the aliens became the thematic and narrative core of the series. The film series resulted in a media franchise with novels, comic books, video games, and merchandise. A prequel series was started with Prometheus (2012) and continued with Alien: Covenant (2017).

item.title: Alien vs. Predator (2004 film)
item.description:
Alien vs. Predator (2004 film) ðŸ”—

A 2004 science fiction action horror film directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, Alien vs. Predator brings together the titular creatures from the Alien and Predator franchises. The story draws inspiration from a 1989 comic book and incorporates elements of Aztec mythology and the writings of Erich von DÃ¤niken.

Plot ðŸ”—

In Antarctica, a Predator ship melts a hole in the ice, revealing a buried pyramid. Charles Weyland assembles a team to investigate. The team discovers evidence of an ancient civilization and a sacrificial chamber. Three Predators arrive and descend into the pyramid, where they encounter the humans and awakened Xenomorphs. Battles ensue, and Lex Woods and Sebastian De Rosa learn about the Predators’ history on Earth through hieroglyphs. They discover that the Predators have been visiting Earth for millennia, teaching humans to build pyramids and using them for rite of passage rituals involving Xenomorphs. Lex and Sebastian ally with a Predator named Scar to prevent the Xenomorphs from escaping. Scar destroys the pyramid, but the Xenomorph Queen attacks. Lex and Scar defeat the Queen, and an elder Predator gifts Lex a spear. A Predalien chestburster erupts from Scar’s body on the Predator spaceship.

Cast ðŸ”—

Sanaa Lathan stars as Alexa “Lex” Woods, an experienced guide. Raoul Bova plays Professor Sebastian De Rosa, an Italian archaeologist. Lance Henriksen portrays Charles Bishop Weyland, the head of Weyland Corporation. Ewen Bremner is Dr. Graeme Miller, the main scientist. Colin Salmon plays Maxwell Stafford, Weyland’s assistant. Tommy Flanagan is Mark Verheiden, a member of the armed escort. Tom Woodruff Jr. plays the Alien/Grid, and Ian Whyte plays the Predator/Scar and other Predators.

Production ðŸ”—

Fifth Alien film and sequel ðŸ”—

James Cameron had been working on a fifth Alien film, and Ridley Scott had a concept to explore the origins of the alien creatures. However, upon learning of Alien vs. Predator, Cameron ceased work, believing it would damage the franchise. Ridley Scott also expressed disinterest in the Alien vs. Predator films.

Development ðŸ”—

The concept originated from the Aliens versus Predator comic book. Screenwriter Peter Briggs created a spec screenplay in 1990â€“1991. The project was delayed due to Alien Resurrection. Paul W. S. Anderson pitched John Davis a story adapting the Machiko Noguchi series. Anderson began working on the film after completing the script for Resident Evil: Apocalypse, with Shane Salerno co-writing.

Story and setting ðŸ”—

Influenced by Erich von DÃ¤niken and Aztec mythology, Anderson depicted Predators teaching humans to build pyramids and being treated as gods. The Predators would use Earth for rite of passage rituals every 100 years, hunting Aliens. If overwhelmed, the Predators would use self-destruct weapons. H. P. Lovecraft’s At the Mountains of Madness and the Aliens vs. Predator comic series influenced the story. The film is set on Bouvet Island in Antarctica.

Casting ðŸ”—

Lance Henriksen was the first actor cast, maintaining continuity with the Alien series. He plays Charles Bishop Weyland, tying into the Weyland-Yutani Corporation. Sanaa Lathan was cast as Alexa Woods. Arnold Schwarzenegger was considered for a cameo as Major Alan “Dutch” Schaeffer from Predator. Sigourney Weaver declined to participate.

Filming and set designs ðŸ”—

Production began in 2003 at Barrandov Studios in Prague. Richard Bridgland designed sets, props, and vehicles. 25 to 30 life-sized sets were constructed, including interiors of the pyramid. The pyramid’s designs were influenced by Egyptian, Cambodian, and Aztec civilizations. Miniatures were used to enhance realism.

Visual effects and creatures ðŸ”—

Amalgamated Dynamics, Inc. (ADI) designed costumes, miniatures, and effects. The Predators’ wrist blades were extended, and a larger mechanical plasma caster was created. Each Predator was given a unique mask. A hydraulic Alien puppet was created for faster movements. CGI use was minimized. The Alien queen was filmed using practical, puppet, and computer-generated versions.

Music ðŸ”—

Harald Kloser composed the film’s score, recorded in London. The score album was released on iTunes and CD, receiving mixed reviews.

Release ðŸ”—

Home media ðŸ”—

Alien vs. Predator was released on VHS, DVD, and PSP UMD Movies. The DVD included audio commentaries, a “Making of” featurette, and deleted scenes. An “Extreme Edition” and an “Unrated Edition” were also released.

Reception ðŸ”—

Box office ðŸ”—

Alien vs. Predator grossed $177.4 million worldwide.

Critical response ðŸ”—

The film received generally negative reviews. Rotten Tomatoes reported 21% positive reviews, with the consensus being “Gore without scares and cardboard cut-out characters make this clash of the monsters a dull sit.” Metacritic gave the film a score of 29 out of 100, indicating “generally unfavorable” reviews.

Other media ðŸ”—

Sequel ðŸ”—

Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem was released in December 2007.

Related film ðŸ”—

The Predator (2018) featured Lex Wood’s Xenomorph-bone spear.

Related video games ðŸ”—

Several video games were released, including Alien vs. Predator (mobile) and Aliens vs. Pinball.

item.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
item.description:
Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

A 1977 American science fiction drama film directed and written by Steven Spielberg. It tells the story of Roy Neary, an everyday blue-collar worker in Indiana, and Jillian, a single mother, whose lives are changed after encounters with unidentified flying objects.

Plot ðŸ”—

In 1977, French scientist Claude Lacombe and his team examine Flight 19, found abandoned in the Sonoran Desert, and the SS Cotopaxi, found in the Gobi Desert. Near Indianapolis, Roy Neary has a close encounter with a UFO, becoming obsessed with a mountain shape. Jillian Guiler’s son, Barry, is abducted by a UFO. Lacombe’s team investigates increasing UFO activity, discovering a five-tone musical phrase. The coordinates point to Devils Tower in Wyoming. Roy and Jillian, along with others experiencing visions, head to Devils Tower, which is being evacuated by the US Army. They reach the site as UFOs appear. Scientists communicate with the UFOs using light and sound. A mothership arrives, releasing humans and animals, including Barry. Roy is chosen to join the extraterrestrials, entering the mothership as it departs.

Cast ðŸ”—

Richard Dreyfuss stars as Roy Neary, an electrical lineman. FranÃ§ois Truffaut plays Claude Lacombe, a French scientist. Teri Garr is Ronnie Neary, Roy’s wife, and Melinda Dillon portrays Jillian Guiler. Cary Guffey plays Barry Guiler, Jillian’s son. Bob Balaban appears as David Laughlin, Lacombe’s assistant.

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

The film’s inspiration came from Steven Spielberg’s childhood experience watching a meteor shower. He developed a deal with Columbia Pictures in 1973. J. Allen Hynek, a UFO consultant, was hired. NASA declined to cooperate.

Filming ðŸ”—

Principal photography began in May 1976. Filming locations included Burbank, California; Devils Tower National Monument in Wyoming; airship hangars in Mobile, Alabama; and a railroad depot in Bay Minette, Alabama. The Sonora Desert sequence was filmed at the Dumont Dunes, California, and the Dharmsala-India exteriors were filmed near Mumbai, India. Technical and budgetary problems arose during filming.

Visual effects ðŸ”—

Douglas Trumbull served as the visual effects supervisor, and Carlo Rambaldi designed the extraterrestrials. The mothership was designed by Ralph McQuarrie and built by Greg Jein. The look of the ship was inspired by an oil refinery Spielberg saw at night in India.

Post-production ðŸ”—

Michael Kahn was the film editor. Pick-ups were commissioned, with John A. Alonzo, LÃ¡szlÃ³ KovÃ¡cs, and Douglas Slocombe working on them.

Music ðŸ”—

John Williams composed the film score, including the iconic five-tone motif. Spielberg called Williams’s work “When You Wish Upon a Star meets science fiction.” Phillip Dodds from ARP Instruments installed the synthesizer on set and was cast as Jean Claude.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of humanity’s readiness to join the cosmos, the impact of new technologies, and spiritual yearning. Judeo-Christian analogies are present, with Devils Tower paralleling Mount Sinai. Communication and tolerance are also highlighted.

Release and reception ðŸ”—

Box office ðŸ”—

The film premiered in New York City on November 16, 1977, and was released nationally in December. It became a box office success, grossing over $300 million worldwide.

Critical reception ðŸ”—

Reviews were mostly positive, with praise for Spielberg’s vision and the film’s climax. Some critics noted a lack of warmth compared to Star Wars.

Reissues and home media ðŸ”—

Several versions of the film have been released, including the original theatrical version, the Special Edition (1980), and the Director’s Cut (1998). The Special Edition added scenes, including the interior of the mothership, while the Director’s Cut removed the mothership interior.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film received numerous awards and nominations, including Academy Awards, British Academy Film Awards, and Golden Globe Awards. It was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry in 2007.

Legacy ðŸ”—

Close Encounters is credited with launching the reemergence of science fiction films in the 1980s. Spielberg donated to the Planetary Society for extraterrestrial research.

item.title: Interdimensional UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Interdimensional UFO Hypothesis ðŸ”—

The interdimensional UFO hypothesis (IUH) proposes that unidentified flying object (UFO) sightings result from encounters with other “dimensions” existing alongside our own. Ufologists such as Meade Layne, John Keel, J. Allen Hynek, and Jacques VallÃ©e have advanced this hypothesis. Proponents suggest that UFOs are a modern manifestation of phenomena throughout human history, previously attributed to mythological or supernatural beings.

History ðŸ”—

Concepts similar to “other dimensions” exist in various religious and mystical traditions.

Pre-modern history ðŸ”—

Islamic mysticism, specifically Sufism, includes the concept of al-ghayb, referring to the hidden and unseen. Within this tradition, â€˜Älam al-mithÄl, or “the world of similitude,” is an intermediary realm between the physical and spiritual worlds, inhabited by intelligent non-human entities like jinn and angels. Helena Blavatsky, founder of Theosophy, also contributed to the concept of other dimensions.

Theorists ðŸ”—

Background ðŸ”—

In the 19th century, spiritualists believed in “other dimensions.” H.P. Blavatsky popularized the term “planes,” proposing a cosmology of seven planes. The term “ether” was adopted from ancient Greek via Victorian physics and incorporated into occult writings. Charles Webster Leadbeater and Annie Besant introduced the “etheric plane” and “etheric body” in Theosophy. The first use of the word, as inter-dimensional, is in a novel by Z Gale of 1906.

Meade Layne and ‘Ether Ships’ ðŸ”—

On July 4, 1947, occultist Meade Layne claimed that flying discs were “etheric.” Layne, claiming telepathic communication with “people in the saucers,” argued that objects could materialize from an etheric state. He believed these visitors were human beings from another world with good intentions. Layne is regarded as the earliest proponent of the interdimensional hypothesis.

John Keel and ‘Ultraterrestrials’ ðŸ”—

John Keel coined the term “ultraterrestrials” to describe UFO occupants as non-human entities existing in undetectable energy wavelengths. In his 1970 book UFOs: Operation Trojan Horse, Keel argued that a non-human intelligence has staged events to propagate erroneous belief systems, including monsters, ghosts, demons, fairies, vampires, mystery airships, mystery aeroplanes, mystery helicopters, anomalous creature sightings, poltergeist phenomena, balls of light, and UFOs.

Hynek and VallÃ©e ðŸ”—

J. Allen Hynek, an astronomer and scientific advisor to the U.S. Air Force UFO studies (Project Sign, Project Grudge, and Project Blue Book), pioneered the “Close Encounter” classification system. Jacques VallÃ©e, a student of Hynek’s, served as the inspiration for the French researcher portrayed by FranÃ§ois Truffaut in the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. In their 1975 book The Edge of Reality, VallÃ©e and Hynek considered the possibility of “interlocking universes.” VallÃ©e’s 1969 book Passport to Magonia argues for a “parallel universe co-existing with our own.” VallÃ©e’s 1990 paper “Five Arguments Against the Extraterrestrial Origin of Unidentified Flying Objects” summarizes his objections to the extraterrestrial hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

The 2008 film Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull utilizes the interdimensional hypothesis, describing ancient aliens traveling into “the space between the spaces.” The 2014 movie Interstellar employs a mix of the interdimensional and time-traveler hypotheses, with future humans evolving to exist in five dimensions and building a tesseract inside a black hole.

Other contrasting hypothesis ðŸ”—

The IUH contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (UFOs are from outside Earth) and the psychosocial hypothesis (UFOs are psychological or social phenomena). Other contrasting hypotheses include:

  • Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis
  • Space animal hypothesis
  • Time-traveler hypothesis
