item.title: Aliens Stole My Body (film)
item.description:
Aliens Stole My Body (film) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the 2020 American adventure science fiction comedy film Aliens Stole My Body, directed by Sean McNamara. It is based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville and serves as a sequel to the 2018 film Aliens Ate My Homework. The film features a cast including Jayden Greig, George Takei, and Dan Payne. It premiered on Netflix on August 4, 2020, in the United States.

Plot ðŸ”—

The crew of the Ferkel returns to Earth to enlist Rod Allbright and Elspeth McMasters to stop BKR, who has escaped from prison. Rod’s friend Mickey joins them as they travel to Mentat to rescue Rod’s father. BKR needs Rod’s father’s knowledge to trap the entire galaxy in a single moment in time. The Allbright family confronts BKR near a black hole.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright, George Takei as the voice of Phil the Plant, and Dan Payne as Grakker. Other cast members include Tristan Risk as Madame Pong, Alex Zahara as Tar Gibbons, Lauren McNamara as Elspeth McMasters, Sean Quan as Mickey, Ty Consiglio as Billy Becker, Sandy Robson as Art Allbright, Kirsten Robeck as Gwen Allbright, Christian Convery as Eric Allbright, Carmela Guizzo as Linda Allbright, and Travis Turner as Lackey. Bruce Coville makes a cameo appearance.

Differences from the book ðŸ”—

The film combines plot elements from The Search for Snout and Aliens Stole My Body, the third and fourth books in the Rod Allbright Alien Adventures series, while also introducing original elements.

item.title: Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film)
item.description:
Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film) ðŸ”—

A 2018 American science fiction comedy film directed by Sean McNamara, based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville. The film features an ensemble cast including Jayden Greig, William Shatner, Dan Payne, and Alex Zahara. It premiered on Netflix on March 6, 2018, and was followed by a sequel, Aliens Stole My Body (2020).

Plot ðŸ”—

Rod and his cousin Elspeth encounter a group of extraterrestrial lawmen, the Galactic Patrol, after a spaceship crashes through his window and lands on his homework. They must assist the aliens in stopping the plans of the interplanetary criminal BKR, who is disguised on Earth as Billy Becker, a school bully who torments Rod.

Cast ðŸ”—

  • Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright
  • William Shatner as the voice of Phil the Plant
  • Dan Payne as Grakker
  • Tristan Risk as Madame Pong

The Alien franchise is a science fiction horror and action media franchise that began with the 1979 film Alien. The series centers on Ellen Ripley’s battles with the extraterrestrial Xenomorph and the prequel series following the android David 8 and the Engineers. The franchise is owned by 20th Century Studios.

Created by: Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett Original Work: Alien (1979) Owner: 20th Century Studios Years Active: 1979â€“present

Premise ðŸ”—

The franchise depicts deadly encounters between humanity and the Xenomorph, a hostile extraterrestrial species. Humanity is a space-faring species, and space journeys require cryosleep. The megacorporation Weyland-Yutani Corp seeks to profit from the Aliens, manipulating and endangering characters. The series also explores the origin of the human race, with the Engineers sacrificing themselves to spark the genesis of mankind.

Background ðŸ”—

Dan O’Bannon and Ronald Shusett collaborated on the script for Alien. Brandywine Productions bought the script, and 20th Century Fox invested millions after the success of Star Wars. The Ripley character was initially to be played by Tom Skerritt, but Sigourney Weaver was cast instead. Ridley Scott directed the film. H. R. Giger designed the alien creature and derelict ship, MÅ“bius created the spacesuits, and Ron Cobb provided the industrial design for the sets.

James Cameron expressed interest in continuing the Alien story in 1983. After Cameron’s The Terminator became a hit, he and Gale Anne Hurd were approved to direct and produce Aliens. Following the second film, Weaver was not interested in returning, but she was offered a $5 million salary and a producer credit to make Alien 3. Alien 3 faced script difficulties, trouble securing a director, and studio interference.

Production on Alien Resurrection began in 1996. Weaver joined the project after being offered an $11 million salary and more creative control. The script resurrected the Ripley character via human cloning. Joss Whedon later said that he thought it had done “everything wrong” with his script.

item.title: Nazi UFOs
item.description:
Conspiracy theories alleging connections between UFOs and Nazi Germany ðŸ”—

This article explores the conspiracy theories linking UFOs to Nazi Germany, asserting that the Nazis attempted to develop advanced aircraft and spacecraft before and during World War II. It further claims that these craft survived in secret underground bases in Antarctica, South America, or the United States, along with their creators.

Early UFOs as possible Nazi technology ðŸ”—

This section discusses how unusual aerial sightings during and after World War II were initially attributed to novel Nazi technology. During the Cold War, speculation arose that the Soviets might be deploying captured or reverse-engineered Nazi technology.

Foo fighters ðŸ”—

During World War II, Allied and Axis personnel witnessed unusual aerial phenomena called “foo fighters.” While some reports were dismissed as misperceptions, others were taken seriously, leading scientists like Luis Alvarez to investigate. Allied intelligence suspected some foo fighters were advanced German aircraft or weapons, given Germany’s technological innovations like V-1 and V-2 missiles and the Me 262 jet fighter.

Ghost rockets ðŸ”—

In 1946, rocket- or missile-shaped UFOs, known as “ghost rockets,” were sighted primarily in Sweden and nearby countries. Finnish observers made the first reports in February 1946. Investigations suggested some sightings were meteors, but others displayed characteristics inconsistent with meteors, such as maneuverability. It was initially believed that the ghost rockets originated from the former German rocket facility at PeenemÃ¼nde and were Soviet tests of captured German missiles.

Flying discs ðŸ”—

Following Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting of crescent-shaped objects, speculation about German technology resurfaced. Project Sign personnel noted similarities between the Horten brothers’ flying wing designs and some UFO reports. Edward J. Ruppelt, the first head of Project Blue Book, noted that the Germans had several radical aircraft and guided missiles under development at the end of WWII.

The earliest media assertion of German flying saucers appeared in the Italian newspaper Il Giornale d’Italia in 1950. Professor Giuseppe Belluzzo claimed that flying discs were designed and studied in Germany and Italy as early as 1942.

In the same month, German technician Rudolf Schriever claimed to Der Spiegel that he designed a craft powered by rotating turbine blades while working at BMW’s Prague works until April 1945. He said his designs were stolen, and he believed Czech agents built his craft for a foreign power.

In 1953, German engineer Georg Klein claimed that designs similar to Avro Canada’s Avrocar had been developed during the Nazi era. Klein identified two types of supposed German flying disks: one developed by Richard Miethe in Breslau and another developed by Rudolf Schriever and Klaus Habermohl in Prague.

Aeronautical engineer Roy Fedden stated in 1945 that the only craft that could approach the capabilities attributed to flying saucers were those being designed by the Germans towards the end of the war.

Nazi UFO conspiracy theories ðŸ”—

By the 1960s, fringe authors began circulating tales of Nazi UFOs tied to the occult or aliens. These theories reference various potential code-names or sub-classifications of Nazi UFO craft.

German UFO literature often aligns with documented history regarding Nazi Germany’s claim to New Swabia in Antarctica and its research into advanced propulsion technology.

The Morning of the Magicians ðŸ”—

Le Matin des Magiciens, a 1960 book by Louis Pauwels and Jacques Bergier, made claims about the Vril Society of Berlin. Later writers, including Jan van Helsing, Norbert-JÃ¼rgen Ratthofer, and Vladimir Terziski, connected the Vril Society with UFOs, claiming the society contacted an alien race and developed spacecraft to reach them. They allege that the Vril Society, in partnership with the Thule Society and the Nazi Party, developed flying disc prototypes and retreated to a base in Antarctica after the Nazi defeat.

The works of Ernst ZÃ¼ndel ðŸ”—

Ernst ZÃ¼ndel’s Samisdat Publishers claimed that flying saucers were Nazi secret weapons launched from an underground base in Antarctica, aiming to conquer Earth and other planets. ZÃ¼ndel also sold seats on an exploration team to locate the polar entrance to the hollow earth.

Miguel Serrano’s book ðŸ”—

In 1978, Miguel Serrano published El CordÃ³n Dorado: Hitlerismo EsotÃ©rico, claiming that Adolf Hitler was an Avatar of Vishnu communing with Hyperborean gods in an underground Antarctic base in New Swabia. Serrano predicted that Hitler would lead a fleet of UFOs from the base to establish the Fourth Reich.

Die Glocke ðŸ”—

Die Glocke (“The Bell”) was a purported top-secret Nazi scientific technological device or Wunderwaffe. First described by Igor Witkowski in Prawda o Wunderwaffe (2000) and popularized by Nick Cook, it was associated with Nazi occultism, antigravity, and free energy suppression research. Claims about Die Glocke have been criticized as fictional and a hoax.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section lists examples of Nazi UFOs appearing in popular culture, including:

  • Robert A. Heinlein’s Rocket Ship Galileo (1947) featuring a Nazi Moon base.
  • The video game Medal of Honor: Frontline (2002) featuring a Nazi UFO.
  • The movie Iron Sky (2012) featuring a Nazi base on the moon launching an assault on Earth with flying saucers.
  • Revell releasing a scale model kit of a Nazi flying saucer called “Haunebu II” (2018), which was later removed from production due to historical inaccuracies.
  • The video game Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus (2017) featuring “Haunebu-V” craft manufactured in Nazi-controlled Roswell, New Mexico.
  • The Commando Comic Flight of Fancy (2017) featuring the Schriever Flugkreisel.
  • The second season finale of 30 Coins (2023) mentioning Haunebu UFOs as copies of Nazca UFOs.

Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they are portrayed in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It includes a link to a separate article listing alleged extraterrestrial beings. A banner at the top indicates that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and needs more citations.

History ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from antiquity and progressing through modern times.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This subsection covers early depictions of extraterrestrials, beginning with Lucian’s 2nd-century satire True History, where the protagonist visits the Moon and finds it inhabited by warring factions. It emphasizes how early concepts of extraterrestrials were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed aliens as human-like, as exemplified by Voltaire’s MicromÃ©gas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac.

Early 20th Century ðŸ”—

This section discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species on alien depictions, leading to the creation of non-humanoid aliens in fiction. Camille Flammarion’s works are mentioned as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also highlights H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon as influential works that explored the implications of evolution and alien civilizations. The rise of pulp magazines and their role in popularizing science fiction with various alien tropes are also discussed, including the common use of Martians, Venusians, and other Solar System inhabitants. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is noted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times ðŸ”—

This section covers the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. It mentions The Eternaut by HÃ©ctor GermÃ¡n Oesterheld, an Argentine work that critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that popularized the “grey alien” archetype. The influence of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, is highlighted, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budgetary constraints. The section concludes by mentioning the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

item.title: Alien invasion
item.description:
Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

Alien invasion, also known as space invasion, is a prevalent theme in science fiction stories and films. It involves extraterrestrial lifeforms invading Earth with various motives, such as exterminating or enslaving humanity, harvesting humans for food, stealing resources, or destroying the planet. This theme is a subgenre of invasion literature, popularized by H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds, and is a type of first contact science fiction. Experts consider an actual alien invasion unlikely due to the immense costs involved.

Origins ðŸ”—

This section discusses the origins of the alien invasion theme in fiction. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) is considered the seminal alien invasion story, establishing themes like first contact and interplanetary war. However, earlier stories exist, such as Robert Potter’s The Germ Growers (1892), which features a covert alien invasion. The section also mentions Wells’ proposed guerrilla war scenario in The War of the Worlds. Garrett P. Serviss’ Edison’s Conquest of Mars, an unauthorized sequel to The War of the Worlds, depicts Thomas Edison leading a counterattack on Mars. The reprinting of The War of the Worlds in the United States in 1927 coincided with the Golden Age of Science Fiction. John W. Campbell and other science fiction writers, including Isaac Asimov, Arthur C. Clarke, Clifford D. Simak, and Robert A. Heinlein, further developed the theme.

Variations ðŸ”—

This section explores different variations of the alien invasion theme.

Alien Infiltration ðŸ”—

This variation involves invaders taking human form and infiltrating society, even taking control of command positions. Their goal may be to take over the world or prepare for a full-scale invasion. This theme reflects Cold War fears of communist infiltration. The Reptilian conspiracy theory is mentioned as a real-world belief in covert alien infiltration.

Beneficial Alien Invasion ðŸ”—

This variation presents aliens colonizing Earth to “civilize” humanity or secretly aiding humans to prevent self-destruction. Henry Slesar’s The Delegate from Venus is mentioned. Examples include Klaatu and Gort in The Day the Earth Stood Still, Gene Roddenberry’s The Questor Tapes and Star Trek episode “Assignment: Earth”, Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Crest of the Stars, the film Arrival, and David Brin’s Uplift Universe series.

Invasion by Humans ðŸ”—

This variation reverses the roles, with humans invading or attacking extraterrestrial lifeforms. Examples include the short story Sentry, the video game Phantasy Star II, The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury, the Imperium of Man in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Invaders from Earth by Robert Silverberg, Ender’s Game by Orson Scott Card, and the movies Battle for Terra, Planet 51, and Avatar.

Feasibility ðŸ”—

This section discusses the feasibility of an actual alien invasion. Seth Shostak of the SETI Institute believes it’s unlikely due to resource availability and the likelihood of initial contact being through robots. David Morrison of NASA-Ames Research Center suggests first contact would be via radio communication.

item.description:
UFO (1956 film) ðŸ”—

A 1956 American semi-documentary film that explores the development of the UFO phenomenon in the United States. It is noted for its use of documentary clips that have been featured in other UFO-related media.

Origins and plot ðŸ”—

In 1952, Hollywood producer Clarence Greene, after witnessing an unusual aerial object, contacted US Air Force public information officer Albert M. Chop. Intrigued, Greene decided to create a documentary about UFOs, using film footage provided by Chop. The film begins in 1947, covering early UFO sightings like the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Mantell UFO incident, and the Gorman Dogfight. It follows the evolution of UFOs as a cultural fad and a concern for the US Air Force, including the history of Project Sign. The film then focuses on Albert M. Chop, who is assigned as the public information officer at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio. Chop initially debunks UFOs but gradually changes his views, believing they are unknown aircraft, possibly extraterrestrial. By 1952, Chop is in Washington, D.C., as the press spokesman for Project Blue Book. The documentary analyzes the Mariana UFO Incident of 1950 and the 1952 UFO film taken near the Great Salt Lake in Utah by Delbert Newhouse. The film concludes with the 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident, where Chop played a central role, ultimately stating his belief that UFOs are a real, physical phenomenon of unknown origin.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes Willis Sperry, Nicholas Mariana, Delbert Newhouse, Wendell Swanson, and U.S. Air Force General John A. Samford as themselves. Tom Towers plays Albert M. (Al) Chop, Floyd Burton plays Major Dewey Fournet, Gene Coughlan plays an editor from the Dayton Daily News, Bert Freed plays a Colonel, Stan Gordon plays a reporter, Marie Kenna plays Mrs. Albert Chop, Harry Morgan provides voices, Robert Phillips plays Captain Edward Ruppelt, William Solomon plays a German scientist, and Olan Soule is a narrator.

This is a description of the 2009 film Alien Trespass, directed by R.W. Goodwin. The film is a science-fiction comedy that pays homage to the B movies of the 1950s.

Plot ðŸ”—

The story is set in 1957 in California’s Mojave Desert. Astronomer Ted Lewis and his wife Lana are observing a meteor shower when something crashes nearby. Ted investigates and discovers an alien spaceship. His body is then taken over by Urp, a well-meaning alien who is searching for Ghota, a one-eyed monster that escaped from the ship. Ghota consumes people to grow and multiply, threatening Earth. Urp enlists the help of Tammy, a local waitress, to stop Ghota. The local police, Chief Dawson and Officer Vern, are skeptical. Urp and Tammy hunt down Ghota, and they eventually fall in love. At the end, Urp returns to his home planet, leaving Tammy to pursue her dreams.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Eric McCormack as Ted Lewis/Urp, Jenni Baird as Tammy, Robert Patrick as Vernon, Jody Thompson as Lana Lewis, and Dan Lauria as Chief Dawson. Other cast members include Sarah Smyth, Aaron Brooks, Andrew Dunbar, Dayna Reid, Chelah Horsdal, Sage Brocklebank, Jonathon Young, and Tom McBeath.

Analysis ðŸ”—

The film replicates the look and feel of 1950s science fiction films, with the exception of being in color. The film uses the trope of monsters terrorizing small desert towns, which was common in 1950s B movies due to lower production costs. The character of Lana Lewis is depicted as a “sexpot,” a common archetype in 1950s science fiction films. The Ghota is similar to B.O.B. from Monsters vs. Aliens. The romance between Urp and Tammy is reminiscent of The Day the Earth Stood Still. Director Goodwin states that the film takes elements from The Day the Earth Stood Still, It Came from Outer Space, and The War of the Worlds.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received mixed reviews. Rotten Tomatoes gives it a 38% approval rating, with the consensus being that it loses its charm due to tedious dialogue and cheesy special effects. Roger Ebert gave the film two out of four stars, stating that it was a labor of love but questioning whether there was a demand for cheesy 1950s sci-fi movies. Jeannette Catsoulis of The New York Times described the film as a charming but pointless homage. Betsy Sharkey of the Los Angeles Times felt that the film stayed too true to the era and genre, forgetting to entertain. IGN praised the film’s recreation of the 1950s aesthetic but found that it couldn’t decide whether to emulate or satirize the genre. Ty Burr of The Boston Globe felt that the film was superior to Monsters vs. Aliens. Entertainment Weekly gave the film a “B+” rating, praising its warm tone and anti-CGI look. Gary Westfahl considers the film an overlooked gem that captures the charm of 1950s science fiction films.

See also ðŸ”—

The article lists other films related to the genre, including Earth vs. the Flying Saucers, Forbidden Planet, Invaders from Mars, Mars Attacks!, and The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra.

Sources ðŸ”—

The article cites several sources, including reviews by Roger Ebert, Gary Westfahl, and articles from AMC.com.

References ðŸ”—

The article includes a list of references to support the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

The article provides links to the film’s official website, IMDb page, Rotten Tomatoes page, TCM Movie Database page, and articles from The New York Times, AMCtv.com, and Starlog magazine.

item.title: Roswell incident
item.description:
UFO Legend Caused by 1947 Balloon Crash: The Roswell Incident ðŸ”—

This article delves into the Roswell incident, a cornerstone of UFO lore, tracing its origins from a 1947 military balloon crash to the elaborate conspiracy theories that persist today.

Newspaper Headline and Incident Overview ðŸ”—

The Roswell Daily Record’s July 8, 1947, issue announced the “capture” of a “flying saucer” by the Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF). The incident occurred between June 4 and July 10, 1947, in Lincoln County, New Mexico. The military balloon debris recovered near Roswell became the basis for conspiracy theories alleging the recovery of an extraterrestrial spacecraft.

1947 Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

The Roswell incident occurred during the 1947 flying disc craze, which included events such as the Kenneth Arnold sighting, the Flight 105 sighting, the Rhodes photographs, the Twin Falls hoax, and the Maury Island hoax.

Military Balloon Crash ðŸ”—

In 1947, the United States launched Project Mogul balloons from Alamogordo Army Air Field to detect Soviet atomic tests. On June 4, researchers lost contact with a balloon train near Corona, New Mexico, where rancher W.W. “Mac” Brazel later discovered debris. Initially unaware of the flying disc craze, Brazel consulted his uncle, Hollis Wilson, who suggested the debris might be from a “flying disk.”

Brazel reported his find to Sheriff George Wilcox, who contacted Roswell Army Air Field (RAAF). Major Jesse Marcel and Captain Sheridan Cavitt were assigned to collect the material. RAAF public information officer Walter Haut issued a press release about the recovered “flying disc.” The announcement made international headlines but was retracted within a day, with the army claiming it was a weather balloon.

General Roger Ramey and weather officer Irving Newton identified the material as pieces of a weather balloon at a press conference. The Roswell Daily Record noted the absence of engine or metal parts in the wreckage. Jesse Marcel described the wreckage as “parts of the weather device” composed of “tinfoil and broken wooden beams.” Colonel Marcellus Duffy at Wright Field identified the material as balloon equipment.

UFO Conspiracy Theories (1947â€“1978) ðŸ”—

The 1947 debris retrieval remained relatively obscure for three decades. Belief in UFO cover-ups by the US government became widespread. Hoaxes, legends, and stories of crashed spaceships and alien bodies in New Mexico emerged. The 1947 incident was reinterpreted to fit the public’s increasingly conspiracy-minded outlook.

Aztec Crashed Saucer Hoax ðŸ”—

The 1948 Aztec, New Mexico crashed saucer hoax introduced stories of recovered alien bodies. Con artists convinced Variety columnist Frank Scully to cover their fictitious crash. The hoax narrative included small grey humanoid bodies, metal stronger than any found on Earth, indecipherable writing, and a government coverup.

Hangar 18 ðŸ”—

“Hangar 18” is a non-existent location that many later conspiracy theories allege housed extraterrestrial craft or bodies recovered from Roswell. The idea of alien corpses being stored in an Air Force morgue at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base was mentioned in Scully’s Behind the Flying Saucers, expanded in the 1966 book Incident at Exeter, and became the basis for the 1968 science-fiction novel The Fortec Conspiracy.

In 1974, Robert Spencer Carr alleged that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored in “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson. The Air Force explained that no “Hangar 18” existed at the base. The 1980 film Hangar 18 dramatized Carr’s claims.

Roswell Conspiracy Theories (1978â€“1994) ðŸ”—

Interest in Roswell was rekindled after ufologist Stanton Friedman interviewed Jesse Marcel in 1978. Marcel stated that the “weather balloon” explanation was a cover story and that he now believed the debris was extraterrestrial. In 1979, Marcel was interviewed by Bob Pratt of the National Enquirer, bringing large-scale attention to the story.

Ufologists interviewed Major Marcel’s son, Jesse A. Marcel Jr. M.D., who said that his father had shown him flying saucer debris, including “a small beam with purple-hued hieroglyphics on it.”

Friedman collaborated with William “Bill” Moore and Charles Berlitz to write the 1980 book The Roswell Incident. It popularized Marcel’s account and added the claimed discovery of alien bodies on the Plains of San Agustin.

The Roswell Incident ðŸ”—

The first Roswell conspiracy book, released in October 1980, was The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and Bill Moore. The book argues that an extraterrestrial craft was flying over the New Mexico desert to observe nuclear weapons activity when a lightning strike killed the alien crew. It alleges that the US government engaged in a cover-up. The book claims that in some photographs, the debris recovered by Marcel had been substituted with the debris from a weather device. The book introduced alien bodies purportedly found by archaeologists on the Plains of San Agustin.

Majestic 12 Hoax ðŸ”—

Majestic 12 was the purported organization behind faked government documents delivered anonymously to multiple ufologists in the 1980s. All individuals who received the fake documents were connected to Bill Moore. After the publication of The Roswell Incident, Richard C. Doty and other individuals presenting themselves as Air Force Intelligence Officers approached Moore. They used the unfulfilled promise of hard evidence of extraterrestrial retrievals to recruit Moore, who kept notes on other ufologists and intentionally spread misinformation within the UFO community. The anonymously delivered documents detailed the creation of a likely fictitious Majestic 12 group formed to handle Roswell debris.

At a 1989 Mutual UFO Network conference, Moore confessed that he had intentionally fed fake evidence of extraterrestrials to UFO researchers, including Paul Bennewitz.

Role of Glenn Dennis ðŸ”—

The initial claims of recovered alien bodies came from the secondhand accounts of “Barney” Barnett and “Pappy” Henderson after their deaths. In 1989, Friedman interviewed former mortician Glenn Dennis, who provided an account of extraterrestrial corpses. Dennis claimed to have received calls from the Air Base with questions about body preservation and inquiries about small or hermetically sealed caskets. In 1991, Dennis co-founded a UFO museum in Roswell along with Max Littell and former RAAF public affairs officer Walter Haut.

Dennis provided false names for the nurse who allegedly witnessed the autopsy.

Competing Accounts and Schism ðŸ”—

A proliferation of competing Roswell accounts led to a schism among ufologists in the early 1990s. The two leading UFO societies disagreed on the scenarios presented by Randleâ€“Schmitt and Friedmanâ€“Berliner.

UFO Crash at Roswell ðŸ”—

In 1991, Kevin Randle and Donald Schmitt published UFO Crash at Roswell. It sold 160,000 copies and served as the basis for the 1994 television film Roswell. Randle and Schmitt added testimony from 100 new witnesses. The book claimed that General Arthur Exon had been aware of debris and bodies, but Exon disputed his depiction.

Crash at Corona ðŸ”—

In 1992, Stanton Friedman released Crash at Corona, co-authored with Don Berliner. The book introduced new “witnesses” and added to the narrative by doubling the number of flying saucers to two, and the number of aliens to eight.

The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell ðŸ”—

In 1994, Randle and Schmitt authored another book, The Truth About the UFO Crash at Roswell which claimed a cargo plane delivered alien bodies to Dwight D. Eisenhower. The book abandoned the Barnett crash site on the Plains of San Agustin as lacking evidence. Randle and Schmitt proposed a new crash site 35 miles north of Roswell, based on statements from Jim Ragsdale and Frank Kaufman.

Air Force Response ðŸ”—

The Air Force provided official responses to Roswell conspiracy theories during the mid-1990s under pressure from New Mexico congressman Steven Schiff and the General Accounting Office (GAO). The initial 1994 USAF report admitted that the weather balloon explanation was a cover story for Project Mogul. The following year, The Roswell Report: Fact vs. Fiction in the New Mexico Desert supported this with extensive documentation.

In 1997, the Air Force published a second report, The Roswell Report: Case Closed. It detailed how eyewitness accounts of military personnel loading aliens into “body bags” matched the Air Force’s procedures for retrieving parachute test dummies in insulation bags.

Later Theories and Hoaxes (1994â€“Present) ðŸ”—

Alien Autopsy ðŸ”—

Pseudo-documentaries, most notably Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, have taken a major role in shaping popular opinion of Roswell. In 1995, British entrepreneur Ray Santilli claimed to have footage of an alien autopsy filmed after the 1947 Roswell crash. In a 2006 documentary, Santilli admitted that the footage was fabricated.

The Day After Roswell ðŸ”—

In 1997, retired army intelligence officer Philip J. Corso released The Day After Roswell. Corso

item.title: Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter
item.description:
Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville Encounter ðŸ”—

The Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter, also known as the Hopkinsville Goblins Case or Kelly Green Men Case, is a claimed close encounter with extraterrestrial beings that allegedly occurred near Kelly and Hopkinsville in Christian County, Kentucky, on August 21â€“22, 1955. Ufologists consider it a significant and well-documented UFO incident, while skeptics attribute the reports to misidentification of natural phenomena and “the effects of excitement.” The United States Air Force’s Project Blue Book classified the encounter as a hoax. Psychologists use the incident as an example of pseudoscience.

Claims ðŸ”—

On the evening of August 21, 1955, several adults and children reported to the Hopkinsville police that their farmhouse was under attack by small alien creatures from a spaceship. Elmer Sutton and Billy Ray Taylor claimed to have shot at the creatures, which repeatedly appeared at the doorway and windows. The Kentucky New Era reported the number of creatures as “12 to 15.” Police officers, state troopers, deputy sheriffs, and military police from Fort Campbell investigated the Sutton farmhouse near Kelly, Kentucky, but found no evidence except for broken windows and holes in screens. The residents, including Glennie Lankford and her family, left the house the next day, claiming the creatures had returned.

Press Coverage ðŸ”—

The family’s claims received widespread local and national press coverage. Early articles did not initially describe the creatures as “little green men,” but the color was later added. Descriptions of the creatures varied, but common details included their small size (2 to 4 feet), large pointed ears, claw-like hands, glowing yellow eyes, and spindly legs.

Explanations ðŸ”—

Psychologists Rodney Schmaltz and Scott Lilienfeld use the incident as an example of pseudoscience to teach critical thinking. They suggest intoxication may have played a role in the sighting. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the family misidentified great horned owls, which are nocturnal, have yellow eyes, and can be aggressive. Nickell also notes that meteor sightings occurred around the same time, which could explain Billy Ray Taylor’s claim of seeing a bright light in the sky. Brian Dunning also supports the great horned owl theory, noting the similarities in size and behavior.

UFOlogists ðŸ”—

French UFOlogist Renaud Leclet suggests that the residents likely saw great horned owls. Jerome Clark describes the creatures as “floating” and the sound of bullets hitting them as “resembling bullets striking a metal bucket.” Clark mentions a luminous patch and a green light, which could be explained by foxfire. He also claims that police, Air Force officers, and civilian ufologists found no evidence of a hoax, but Brian Dunning disputes the involvement of Air Force investigators. Allan Hendry notes the case’s duration and the number of witnesses. Project Blue Book classified the case as a hoax.

In Popular Culture ðŸ”—

The Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter has inspired several works of fiction. Steven Spielberg used the event as the basis for his unproduced horror film Night Skies. The 1986 film Critters is loosely based on the encounter. The PokÃ©mon Sableye is believed to be inspired by the alleged goblins. The “hobkins” gremlins in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game are based on the goblins. The Annoyance Theater in Chicago created a musical called “It Came From Kentucky” based on the event. A 2020 episode of the television series Project Blue Book focused on the encounter. The community of Kelly celebrates the event annually with the Little Green Men Days Festival.

item.title: Alien language in science fiction
item.description:
Alien language in science fiction ðŸ”—

This article discusses the concept of alien languages as portrayed in science fiction, tracing its development from early examples to more sophisticated and detailed implementations. It highlights how the treatment of alien languages has evolved alongside the science fiction genre itself.

Understanding alien languages ðŸ”—

This section explores the challenges and approaches to understanding alien languages in science fiction. It notes the common trope of universal translators in space operas, contrasting it with hard science fiction’s focus on the difficulties of interspecies communication. The section mentions C.S. Lewis’s Out of the Silent Planet, where the protagonist uses historical linguistics to decipher a Martian language. Stanislaw Lem’s His Master’s Voice is cited as a critical examination of humanity’s ability to understand extraterrestrial messages. D.R. Merrill’s Lamikorda emphasizes the importance of body language and cultural context in communication.

The section also discusses franchises that have developed their own languages, such as Klingon in Star Trek (created by Marc Okrand), the Zentradi language from Macross, Kryptonese from DC Comics, Cybertronian from Transformers, and Na’vi from Avatar (created by James Cameron with Paul Frommer).

The use of language as a plot device is explored, with examples like Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country, the Star Trek TNG episode “Darmok,” and the film Mars Attacks! The Babylon 5 episode “Into the Fire” illustrates how misunderstandings can arise from phonetic similarities between languages. C.J. Cherryh’s Chanur series and Foreigner universe are mentioned for their focus on linguistic and psychological barriers to communication. Conversely, The Simpsons is cited for its comedic take on the improbable mutual understanding of English by humans and aliens.

The section also references stories with unpronounceable alien tongues, such as Clark Ashton Smith’s tale featuring the sorcerer Eibon and the alien Hziulquoigmnzhah. Mary Doria Russell’s The Sparrow is mentioned for its complex alien language with unique tenses. Carl Sagan’s Contact is cited for its multilayered encrypted messages from extraterrestrials. Ted Chiang’s “Story of Your Life” (and its film adaptation, Arrival) is highlighted for its detailed portrayal of alien communication through complex symbols. Sheila Finch’s The Guild of Xenolinguists is mentioned as a collection of stories about first contact and alien communication.

Other examples include the Unitology language from the game Dead Space, Alienese from Futurama, and the R’lyehian/Cthuvian language from H.P. Lovecraft’s Cthulhu mythos. Robert Sheckley’s “Shall We Have a Little Talk?” describes a language that mutates too rapidly to be learned. China MiÃ©ville’s Embassytown features the Ariekei language, which requires speakers to use two words at once, spoken by genetically engineered human twins.

Bypassing the issue of language ðŸ”—

This section examines how some science fiction avoids the complexities of alien languages through various devices and concepts.

Universal translators ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on devices that seamlessly translate between languages, effectively eliminating language barriers. Examples include Douglas Adams’s babel fish, the TARDIS from Doctor Who, the translator microbes in Farscape, and the universal translator from Star Trek.

Universal language ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the concept of a common language shared by multiple species. Star Wars uses Basic as a universal language. Other examples include Interlac from the Legion of Super-Heroes, Babylon 5, and the Uplift Universe, where multiple “Galactic” languages are used. Stargate SG-1 features a galactic meeting place where races communicate using a language based on atomic structures.

Telepathy ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the use of telepathy as a means of communication. The Vulcans in Star Trek use the Vulcan mind meld. In Ender’s Game, the Buggers communicate telepathically through their queen, highlighting the communication barriers between species.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles, including “Alien language” and “Astrolinguistics.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including academic papers, books, and websites.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to an external resource: “A Primer In SF XENOLINGUISTICS” by Justin B. Rye.

This entry provides information about the 2003 American-Bulgarian science fiction thriller film Alien Hunter. It includes details about the film’s production, plot, cast, and links to external resources.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot summary details a series of events triggered by a mysterious signal. In 1947, a radio operator disappears while investigating a signal from Roswell, New Mexico. In the present day, the same signal reappears, originating from the South Pole. Cryptologist Julian Rome (played by James Spader) is recruited to investigate an alien object discovered in Antarctica. The object, emitting the signal, contains a deadly virus and an alien. The virus kills members of the research team and threatens a global pandemic. A nuclear strike is ordered to contain the threat. Julian communicates with the alien before it is killed, discovering the virus’s potential to destroy all life on Earth. Julian and three others are rescued by an alien spacecraft moments before the nuclear strike. The government covers up the incident, claiming a nuclear reactor meltdown. The film concludes with the alien spacecraft carrying the survivors leaving the solar system.

item.title: Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film)
item.description:
Cowboys & Aliens (2011 film) ðŸ”—

This article provides a detailed overview of the 2011 American science fiction Western film Cowboys & Aliens, directed by Jon Favreau. It covers various aspects of the film, including its plot, cast, production, themes, marketing, release, reception, and home media.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot unfolds in 1873 New Mexico Territory, where an amnesiac outlaw named Jake Lonergan, portrayed by Daniel Craig, awakens with a mysterious metal bracelet attached to his wrist. He finds himself in the town of Absolution, which is soon attacked by aliens. The aliens abduct several townspeople, including Sheriff Taggart and Percy Dolarhyde. Lonergan’s bracelet activates, transforming into a weapon that he uses to shoot down an alien ship. A posse, including Colonel Woodrow Dolarhyde (Harrison Ford) and a mysterious woman named Ella Swenson (Olivia Wilde), forms to track the aliens. Lonergan’s memories gradually return, revealing his past abduction and the death of his lover, Alice. Ella reveals herself to be an alien from another race, who came to Earth to help resist the invaders. The group plans an attack on the aliens’ mothership, resulting in a final confrontation where Ella sacrifices herself to destroy the ship and save Earth.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film features a prominent cast:

  • Daniel Craig as Jake Lonergan, an amnesiac outlaw.
  • Harrison Ford as Woodrow Dolarhyde, a powerful cattleman.
  • Olivia Wilde as Ella Swenson, an alien traveler.
  • Sam Rockwell as Doc, a doctor and saloon owner.
  • Adam Beach as Nat Colorado, Dolarhyde’s Apache right-hand man.
  • Paul Dano as Percy Dolarhyde, Woodrow’s son.
  • Noah Ringer as Emmett Taggart, Taggart’s grandson.
  • Keith Carradine as Sheriff John Taggart.
  • Clancy Brown as Meacham, Absolution’s preacher.

Production ðŸ”—

The production section details the film’s development, casting, writing, filming, design, and visual effects. The project began in 1997, with Universal Pictures and DreamWorks Pictures acquiring film rights to a concept by Scott Mitchell Rosenberg. Jon Favreau joined as director in 2009, and Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford were cast in the lead roles. Filming took place in New Mexico and California in 2010. The film was shot in the anamorphic format on 35mm film to achieve a classic movie feel. Industrial Light & Magic (ILM) created the visual effects, with Legacy Effects producing practical puppet aliens.

Themes ðŸ”—

The film explores themes of redemption, unity against a common enemy, and the clash between low-tech and high-tech cultures. Jon Favreau aimed for a plausible approach to how 19th-century humans could confront technologically superior extraterrestrial beings. The film also draws parallels between the alien invasion and the historical conflicts between European settlers and Native Americans.

Marketing ðŸ”—

The marketing section discusses the challenges of promoting a film with an “inherently comic” title and premise. The studio aimed to convey the film’s serious tone and adventure elements through trailers and presentations at events like San Diego Comic-Con.

Release ðŸ”—

Cowboys & Aliens premiered at San Diego Comic-Con in July 2011 and was released theatrically in the United States and Canada on July 29, 2011. Paramount Pictures released the film in IMAX theaters internationally, and Reliance Entertainment released it in India.

Reception ðŸ”—

The reception section covers the film’s box office performance and critical response. Cowboys & Aliens underperformed at the box office, earning $174.8 million worldwide on a $163 million budget. Critics praised the acting and special effects but criticized the screenplay and tone.

Home Media ðŸ”—

The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray Disc on December 6, 2011, including an extended version, behind-the-scenes featurettes, and commentary with Jon Favreau. In 2024, Kino Lorber released a 4K Blu-ray of the theatrical cut.

Infringement Lawsuit ðŸ”—

Steven John Busti filed a lawsuit against Universal, DreamWorks, Platinum Studios, and Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, claiming copyright infringement. Busti claimed he wrote a preview for his story Cowboys and Aliens in 1994, which was published in the April 1995 issue of Bizarre Fantasy #1. The lawsuit was dismissed.

Historical Legend ðŸ”—

The capsized steamboat that appears in the film is presumed to be the Iron Mountain which, according to legend, steamed out of Vicksburg towing two barges. Two hours later, another boat found the barges adrift. The ship was not found until later, having apparently been refloated by flood waters and carried through a break in a levee, and grounded in a cotton field at Omega Landing, near Tallulah, Louisiana.

item.title: Michigan "swamp gas" UFO reports
item.description:
1966 US UFO Sightings: Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This article details the mass sightings of unidentified flying objects (UFOs) that occurred in Michigan during March 1966, specifically on March 20 and 21. These events became known as the “Michigan ‘swamp gas’ UFO reports” due to the Air Force’s controversial explanation for the sightings.

March 1966 UFO Flap ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the broader context of the Michigan UFO sightings, noting that the Dexter and Hillsdale mass sightings occurred amidst a wave of UFO reports throughout southern Michigan. A map illustrates the locations of reported sightings, including Lima, Milan, Dexter, Hillsdale, and Holland.

Initial Reports ðŸ”—

This section details the initial UFO sightings that preceded the Dexter and Hillsdale incidents. It mentions reports from Washtenaw County residents, sheriffs, and police beginning around 3:50 a.m. on March 14, describing lights moving at high speeds over Lima Township. Sightings were also reported from Monroe, Livingston, Ypsilanti, Dexter, and Sylvania. Sheriff Deputies Buford Bushroe and John Foster, along with personnel at Selfridge Air Force Base, confirmed the sightings. Deputy David Fitzpatrick captured photographs of lights over Milan on March 16.

Dexter Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the events of March 20, 1966, when Frank Mannor, his wife, and son Ronald reported seeing a red “falling star” that hovered over a marshy area near their farmhouse northwest of Dexter. Mannor contacted law enforcement, and Deputy Sheriff Stanley McFadden and his partner David Fitzpatrick investigated. The Mannors described the object as football-shaped with a ‘waffled’ texture, blinking lights, and antennae. Dexter patrolman Robert Hunawil and Dexter Chief of Police Robert Taylor were also witnesses. Approximately 60 people, including law enforcement, neighbors, and the Mannor family, reportedly witnessed the UFO.

Hillsdale Mass Sighting ðŸ”—

This section describes the mass sighting that occurred around 9 p.m. on March 21 at Hillsdale College. Approximately 87 residents of the MacIntyre Residence Hall observed flashing lights hovering over the Arboretum. William Van Horn, Hillsdale County civil defense director, investigated and observed the lights through binoculars. Hillsdale police officers Harold Hess and Jerry Wise also witnessed the object and reported radio damage after the event.

Continued Reports ðŸ”—

This section notes that reports of flying objects, strange sounds, and unexplained lights continued in Dexter and Hillsdale on March 22. On March 23, a teen from Monroe claimed to have taken photos of a UFO. Robert Nichols and his wife reported an object flying across a highway near Holland on March 24. Sightings were also reported over Macomb and Oakland counties, as well as Bad Axe, Flint, and Ann Arbor, on March 29.

National Attention ðŸ”—

This section discusses the national media coverage of the Dexter sightings, noting that papers nationwide reported on the events on March 21. Wire services distributed a drawing of the reported object by a police officer. Various speculations were covered, including a theory that the UFO was filling up on swamp water to recharge its batteries.

Hynek Press Conference ðŸ”—

This section details the involvement of J. Allen Hynek, an Air Force UFO expert, who was dispatched to investigate the Dexter and Hillsdale sightings. On March 25, Hynek held a press conference where he attributed the sightings to “marsh gas,” an explanation that was met with skepticism and derision. He dismissed the Fitzpatrick photograph as being of the moon and Venus.

Reactions ðŸ”—

This section describes the reactions to Hynek’s “swamp gas” explanation. Congressman Gerald R. Ford called for a Congressional investigation into the sightings. Life Magazine and CBS Reports covered the case.

Congressional Hearing ðŸ”—

This section discusses Hynek’s testimony before the House Armed Services Committee on April 6, alongside Air Force Secretary Harold Brown and Bluebook chief Major Hector Quintanilla. Hynek broke with the Air Force’s stance and suggested that some aspects of UFOs merited serious study.

Aftermath and Legacy ðŸ”—

This section examines the long-term impact of the Michigan UFO sightings. The sightings were listed as a top-ten story for 1966 in Michigan. Alan Hynek, who popularized the swamp gas hypothesis, later argued that the topic merited serious study. The phrase “swamp gas” became associated with skepticism of government conclusions. The incident has been referenced in popular culture, including The X-Files and Men in Black.

item.title: Flying saucer
item.description:
Purported disk-shaped aircraft ðŸ”—

This article focuses on the “flying saucer” or “flying disc” as a specific type of unidentified flying object (UFO). It clarifies that the term, popularized in 1947, is distinct from the more general terms UFO or UAP (unidentified anomalous phenomena). The article includes a photograph of an alleged flying saucer taken over Passaic, New Jersey, in 1952.

History ðŸ”—

Precursors ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical roots of the flying saucer concept, predating the 1947 coining of the term. It mentions:

  • Mysterious lights in the sky interpreted as spiritual phenomena in antiquity.
  • 19th-century newspaper reports of massive airships with lights and humming engines.
  • John Martin’s 1878 report in the Denison Daily News describing an object resembling a saucer.
  • The mystery airship sightings in America during 1896 and 1897.
  • “Foo fighters” reported by Allied pilots during World War II.

Alien Raiders (2008 Film) ðŸ”—

This article provides information about the 2008 American science fiction horror film, Alien Raiders.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around a group of armed individuals who take hostages in a grocery store, claiming to hunt alien parasites. The group, led by Ritter, seeks to eliminate the parasites, which arrived on Earth via a meteorite, by identifying and killing infected individuals. They use a gruesome method of cutting off fingers to test for infection. A police officer, Seth, whose stepdaughter works at the store, becomes involved and tries to negotiate with Ritter. The situation escalates with deaths, revelations about the parasites’ hierarchy (females and a king), and the introduction of Charlotte, a former member of Ritter’s group with the ability to identify the infected. The climax involves the discovery that the “king” parasite is hosted by Seth’s stepdaughter, Whitney.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Carlos Bernard as Aaron Ritter, Mathew St. Patrick as Seth Steadman, and Rockmond Dunbar as Kane. Other notable cast members include Courtney Ford as Sterling, Jeffrey Licon as Benny, and Samantha Streets as Whitney. Bonita Friedericy plays Charlotte. The cast list provides a comprehensive overview of the actors and the characters they portray in the film.

Release ðŸ”—

Alien Raiders premiered at Fantastic Fest on September 21, 2008, and was subsequently released directly to DVD by Warner Home Video under the Raw Feed label in September 2008.

Reception ðŸ”—

The film received positive reviews, holding a 100% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes based on six reviews. Critics praised the unexpectedly high quality of the effects and acting, especially considering its low-budget horror film status. The title of the film was criticized.

item.title: Time-traveler UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Time-traveler UFO hypothesis ðŸ”—

The time-traveler hypothesis, also known as chrononaut UFO, future humans, extratempestrial model, and Terminator theory, proposes that unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are humans traveling from the future using advanced technology. This concept has gained recent attention from figures like retired NASA aerospace engineer Larry Lemke, Wisconsin congressman Mike Gallagher, and filmmaker Steven Spielberg. Mainstream scholars consider this hypothesis extremely implausible, and it’s generally viewed as unorthodox even among fringe conspiracy theorists.

Antecedents ðŸ”—

This section explores the origins of the ideas that led to the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Origins of time travel speculation ðŸ”—

This subsection traces the concept of time travel from the future to the past back to its literary origins. Pierre Boitard’s 1861 book Paris avant les hommes is credited with introducing the idea, featuring a man sent back to prehistoric Earth. Camille Flammarion’s 1887 novel Lumen also explored the theme of a soul traveling through different historical periods. The section also notes that while time travel is considered physically impossible by most, theoretical research continues to explore its potential feasibility, with scientists like J. Richard Gott and Ronald Mallet speculating on the possibility of future human time travel.

Speculation of future human evolution ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the history of speculation about the future evolution of mankind. It highlights H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine as an early example of both time travel and speculative evolution. Other authors mentioned include Edgar Rice Burroughs, Olaf Stapledon, Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Baxter, and Cevdet Mehmet KÃ¶semen. The section also identifies climate change, the technological singularity, space travel, and genetic enhancement as potential factors that could alter human evolution, leading to transhuman and posthuman scenarios.

UFOs and initial explanations ðŸ”—

This subsection provides a brief overview of the history of UFO sightings. It mentions reports of unknown objects in the skies dating back to antiquity, as well as the mystery airship sightings of the 1890s and the Foo fighters and ghost rockets during World War II. The modern UFO era is said to have begun in the summer of 1947, following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting. Initial explanations for these sightings ranged from novel US or Soviet technology to misidentification of mundane objects and mass hysteria. Fringe theories included extraterrestrial or interdimensional origins.

Formation and spread ðŸ”—

This section details the development and popularization of the time-traveler UFO hypothesis.

Implausibility of humanoid aliens ðŸ”—

This subsection addresses the common depiction of aliens as humanoids in contactee and alien abduction folklore. It cites George Gaylord Simpson’s 1964 article The Nonprevalence of Humanoids, which argues that it’s unlikely for extraterrestrial intelligence to exist and even more unlikely for it to be humanoid. The section also mentions Stephen Jay Gould’s thought experiment about rewinding evolution, suggesting that humans would likely not evolve again. Biologist Jack Cohen’s view on the implausibility of Grey aliens evolving a physiology similar to humans is also included.

Modern popularization ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the modern resurgence of the time-traveler hypothesis. It mentions Jacques VallÃ©e’s 1975 book The Invisible College as an early example. Other figures and works mentioned include David S. Anderson, Jenny Randles, James Herbert Brennan, and Philip J. Corso and William J. Birnes’ The Day After Roswell, which reported Hermann Oberth’s belief that the Roswell craft could have been a time machine. The History channel series Ancient Aliens is also mentioned for its episodes exploring the concept. Michael P. Masters’ book Identified Flying Objects and The Extratempestrial Model are highlighted for their in-depth exploration of the hypothesis. Tim Peake and Steven Spielberg are mentioned for their recent public comments on the theory.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This subsection lists examples of the time-traveler hypothesis in popular culture. It includes the TV series It’s About Time, Gregory Benford’s novel Timescape, David Drake’s novel Birds of Prey, Michael Crichton’s novel Sphere, the TV film Official Denial, the comic book series Blake and Mortimer, the band Yes, Jordan Peele’s movie Nope, and the movie Interstellar.

Terminology and connection to other theories ðŸ”—

This subsection clarifies the terminology used to describe the hypothesis, noting that while Michael P. Masters uses the term “extratempestrial,” the overall idea is often referred to as “the time-traveler hypothesis.” It also discusses the overlap between the time-traveler hypothesis and the interdimensional hypothesis, with figures like John Ventre and Harold E. Puthoff using the terms interchangeably. The section also notes that the time-traveler hypothesis provides an alternative explanation for the absence of future time travelers, similar to how the extraterrestrial hypothesis addresses Fermi’s paradox.

Criticism ðŸ”—

This section presents criticisms of the time-traveler hypothesis. It notes that the hypothesis is considered pseudoscientific. Neil deGrasse Tyson is quoted as calling the hypothesis illogical, and Robert Sheaffer criticizes Michael P. Masters’ work for relying on the belief that time travel is possible. David J. Darling argues that the extraterrestrial and time-travel hypotheses are equally unlikely and unnecessary. Ian Ridpath suggests that Jim Penniston’s claims about time-traveling UFOs may have been influenced by the film Official Denial. Isaac Arthur is mentioned for debunking the concept as presented in Ancient Aliens. Fabio Costa is quoted as saying that time travel requires two doors, one in the future and one in the past, raising the question of where the time machine is.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics, including Time travel, Posthumanism, Transhumanism, Timeline of the far future, Longtermism, Speculative Evolution, Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, Psychosocial hypothesis, Interdimensional hypothesis, and Space animal hypothesis.

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis ðŸ”—

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as spacecraft or probes from intelligent extraterrestrial civilizations.

Usage of the Term ðŸ”—

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature back to the mid-1960s. Key figures mentioned include French ufologist Jacques VallÃ©e, who used the term in his 1966 book, and French engineer AimÃ© Michel. James E. McDonald and James Harder also used the term in 1968 during a symposium and congressional testimony. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in the Condon Report (1969). Skeptic Philip J. Klass also used the term in his 1968 book.

Chronology ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical context of the ETH, tracing its origins to earlier concepts such as Percival Lowell’s ideas about Martian canals and civilizations, the science fiction writings of H.G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century. The modern ETH took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience, popular culture, and unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups like NICAP and APRO.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits ðŸ”—

This section presents early examples of speculation about extraterrestrial visitors, including an 1864 French newspaper story about the discovery of an alien-like creature. It discusses H.G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” and the “mystery airships” reported in the late 19th century. Mentions comic strips and radio/movie serials like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon, which popularized the idea of alien visitation. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” is also noted for causing public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the surge of UFO sightings in 1947, beginning with Kenneth Arnold’s report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier. It notes that Arnold considered the possibility of extraterrestrial origins and that the ETH was discussed in newspapers and letters to the editor. Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet is mentioned, as is R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that the saucers could be vehicles from Mars or other planets. The section also references Charles Fort’s earlier documentation of unidentified flying objects.

Evolution of Public Opinion ðŸ”—

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions movies from the 1950s depicting flying saucers and aliens, such as “The Day the Earth Stood Still” and “The War of the Worlds.” A 1951 Popular Science poll indicated that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen man-made aircraft, while a small percentage believed they had seen alien craft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A 2002 Roper poll reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP using scientific methods and an agnostic approach. Kopparapu presented a paper in August 2021 supporting the ETH.

Private or Government Studies ðŸ”—

This section highlights private and government studies that have supported the ETH or had members who disagreed with official conclusions. Examples include a 1948 USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins, and the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for unexplained cases. It also mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. The CIA’s internal scientific review and the views of individuals within Project Blue Book, such as Major Dewey Fournet and Edward J. Ruppelt, are discussed. Statements by CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter and Greek physicist Paul Santorini are also included. The section further mentions the COMETA report (1999) and the views of Jean-Jacques Velasco, head of the French UFO investigation SEPRA, and Yves Sillard, head of GEIPAN.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH ðŸ”—

This section presents critical responses to the ETH, noting that there is no scientific proof to back up claims of alien encounters. It states that no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery ðŸ”—

This section discusses the U.S. military’s involvement in investigating UFOs, including the formation of Project Sign in 1947. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also mentions the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which recommended a policy of public debunkery to reduce the number of UFO reports.

Involvement of Scientists ðŸ”—

This section highlights the scientific community’s skepticism towards the ETH. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism and quotes Carl Sagan’s statement about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation. Peter A. Sturrock’s call for examining other possible theories is also included. The section presents results from Sturrock’s polls of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and American Astronomical Society members, showing limited support for the ETH. It summarizes J. Allen Hynek’s seven key reasons for not accepting the ETH, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology ðŸ”—

This section notes that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, which has challenged the claimed phenomenology of UFOs and caused a crisis of confidence among some UFO researchers.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section states NASA’s official position as of 2006, which is that the ETH lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits.

CIA ðŸ”—

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the Robertson Panel in 1953 to debunk data collected by Project Blue Book.

Official White House Position ðŸ”—

This section presents the White House’s official response in November 2011 to petitions asking the U.S. government to acknowledge alien visits and disclose any withholding of government interactions with extraterrestrial beings. The response states that the U.S. government has no evidence of life outside our planet or that an extraterrestrial presence has contacted or engaged any member of the human race.

Counter Critique of the Official Position: Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section discusses the concept of a conspiracy of silence or official cover-up to suppress information about UFOs. It mentions James Harder’s argument in 1968 that significant evidence existed to prove UFOs but had been suppressed. A 1971 survey showed that more Americans believed the government was concealing information about UFOs than believed in the existence of UFOs or the ETH itself. Comments from former NASA astronauts Gordon Cooper and Brian O’Leary about NASA and the government suppressing UFO sightings are also included.

This section focuses on the events surrounding the Kenneth Arnold sighting in 1947 and the subsequent “flying saucer” craze. It details Arnold’s initial report of seeing unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier and his consideration of the possibility of extraterrestrial origins. The section notes the widespread speculation in newspapers about the nature of the “saucers,” including theories about secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria. It mentions Senator Glen Taylor’s comment about wishing the saucers were spaceships from another planet and R. DeWitt Miller’s suggestion that they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The section also cites journalist Edward R. Murrow’s observation that the ETH did not gain widespread attention until about 18 months after Arnold’s sighting.

Evolution of Public Opinion ðŸ”—

This section examines how public opinion regarding UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of the first U.S. poll of public UFO perceptions by Gallup in August 1947, which showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation for the sightings. The section also discusses the influence of movies depicting flying saucers and aliens in the early 1950s. It cites a poll published in Popular Science magazine in 1951, which reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon, exploring the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP with an agnostic approach, involving experts from various fields to collect data and deduce the identity of such UAP. In August 2021, Kopparapu presented a paper supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies ðŸ”—

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or have had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 Top Secret USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s 1948 Top Secret Estimate of the Situation, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for the most perplexing unexplained cases. The section mentions a secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, which also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the CIA’s internal scientific review of UFOs in the early 1950s, noting that some CIA scientists were seriously considering the ETH. The section mentions extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book, including Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who later became a staunch supporter of the ETH. It also cites statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, who urged Congressional action to reduce the dangers from secrecy about unidentified flying objects. The section mentions Greek physicist Paul Santorini’s claim that a 1947 Greek government investigation into the European Ghost rockets concluded that they were extraterrestrial. It also discusses the 1968 Condon Report, noting that many members of the study disagreed with Condon’s methods and biases. The section mentions the 1999 private French COMETA report, which concluded that the hypothesis of extraterrestrial visitors best accounted for the facts. It also discusses Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, who stated that 14% of the cases studied by SEPRA were ‘utterly inexplicable and extraterrestrial’ in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH ðŸ”—

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It notes that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien encounters. It states that despite ardent believers, no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that various UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery ðŸ”—

This section discusses the U.S. military’s investigation of UFOs and its efforts to debunk the ETH. It mentions the formation of Project Sign in 1947, the first official U.S. military UFO study. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation for all UFO reports, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The section also discusses the CIA’s Robertson Panel, which was organized in 1953 to review the Blue Book’s best evidence and recommend an official policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists ðŸ”—

This section examines the scientific community’s response to the ETH. It notes that the scientific community has shown very little support for the ETH, largely accepting the explanation that UFO reports are the result of misinterpretations or hoaxes. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism about the ETH. The section cites Carl Sagan’s observation about the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s statement about the narrow polarization of the UFO debate around the ETH. The section presents the results of a 1973 poll of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics members, which found that about 10% believed that UFOs were vehicles from outer space. It also presents the results of a 1977 poll of American Astronomical Society members, which asked them to assign probabilities to eight possible explanations for UFOs. The section summarizes the primary scientific arguments against ETH, as outlined by J. Allen Hynek, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon in time and space, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology ðŸ”—

This section discusses the argument that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, calling into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section presents NASA’s official standpoint on the ETH, which is that it lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits and that no claims of UFOs as being alien craft have any validity.

CIA ðŸ”—

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

A 2014 Canadian science fiction horror film directed by Colin Minihan, one half of The Vicious Brothers, who also co-produced, wrote, and edited the film. The film stars Brittany Allen, Freddie Stroma, and Melanie Papalia as a group of friends who must defend themselves against an alien onslaught.

Plot ðŸ”—

April and her boyfriend Kyle, along with friends Seth, Melanie, and Lex, head to April’s parents’ cabin for the weekend. After a series of events including a traffic stop and some recreational drug use, they witness a UFO crash in the woods. Investigating, they discover an alien spacecraft and footprints. The group encounters an alien, which they shoot. After this, the group is hunted by aliens, and they seek help from Travis, a family friend of April’s, who explains the government’s alleged treaty with the aliens. The friends try to survive the night as they are picked off one by one. The survivors are eventually abducted and experimented on. Kyle and April are returned to Earth, only to be killed by U.S. Army soldiers who are cleaning up the crash site, covering up the existence of extraterrestrials.

The film stars Brittany Allen as April, Freddie Stroma as Kyle, and Melanie Papalia as Melanie. Other notable cast members include Jesse Moss as Seth, Anja Savcic as Lex, Gil Bellows as Sheriff Murphy, and Michael Ironside as Travis. Sean Rogerson plays Deputy Mitchell, Emily Perkins plays Nancy McPherson, and Jacob Tremblay has an uncredited role as Matty.

Release ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival on April 18, 2014, under the IFC Midnight banner. The Scream Factory later released the film on Blu-ray and DVD on May 12.

Critical reception for Extraterrestrial has been predominantly negative. Reviewers criticized the film for relying too heavily on familiar tropes and clichÃ©s of sci-fi horror movies. Rotten Tomatoes reports an aggregate score of 28%, with the consensus being that the film delivers some gory thrills but is weighed down by clichÃ©s.

A 2006 British comedy film directed by Jonny Campbell and written by William Davies, Alien Autopsy is a fictionalized account of the events surrounding the infamous “alien autopsy” film promoted by Ray Santilli. The film stars Ant & Dec as Santilli and Gary Shoefield.

Plot ðŸ”—

Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield recount their story to a documentary maker. In 1995, they travel to the United States to find Elvis memorabilia. They encounter Harvey, a former US Army cameraman, who offers them a film from 1947 depicting the autopsy of an alien from the Roswell UFO crash.

After returning to England, Ray and Gary discover the film has degraded. To avoid repercussions from their investor, Laszlo Voros, they decide to recreate the autopsy film. They use a mannequin and meat products to create a replica alien and film it in Gary’s sister’s living room.

They sell the film, earning a large sum of money. Voros demands a larger share of the profits but is killed in a mysterious accident. Ray and Gary travel to Argentina to promote the film, where they are followed by reporter Amber Fuentes. They produce a fake interview with a homeless man posing as Harvey to maintain Harvey’s anonymity.

Ray and Gary attempt to restore the original 1947 footage, but after viewing the results, they decide to bury the film.
