This is a description of the 1988 science fiction film Alien from L.A. directed by Albert Pyun, based on the provided Wikipedia article.

Overview ðŸ”—

Alien from L.A. is a 1988 science fiction film directed by Albert Pyun, starring Kathy Ireland. The film centers on a young woman from Los Angeles who discovers an underground civilization in Atlantis. The film is loosely based on Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth. It was also featured on Mystery Science Theater 3000.

Plot ðŸ”—

Wanda Saknussemm, a social misfit from Los Angeles, learns of her archaeologist father’s death in North Africa. While sorting through his belongings, she discovers notes about Atlantis, an alien ship that crashed and sank into the Earth’s center. Wanda accidentally falls into a deep hole and awakens in the underground world of Atlantis. She encounters Gus, a miner, who helps her search for her father, whom she believes is still alive. The Atlanteans consider surface dwellers “aliens” and suspect Wanda and her father of planning an invasion. Wanda becomes a fugitive, pursued by “Government House” and the crime lord Mambino. She receives assistance from Charmin’, a rogue who falls in love with her. Eventually, Wanda is captured by General Rykov, who intends to kill her and her father. Gus helps them escape, and they return to the surface. The film concludes with Wanda rejecting her ex-boyfriend and reuniting with Charmin’ on a beach.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars:

  • Kathy Ireland as Wanda Saknussemm
  • William R. Moses as Guten “Gus” Edway
  • Richard Haines as Professor Arnold Saknussemm
  • Don Michael Paul as Robbie
  • Thom Mathews as “Charmin'”
  • Janie Du Plessis as General Rykov / Shank / Claims Officer
  • Simon Poland as Consul Triton Crassus / The Mailman
  • Linda Kerridge as Roryis Freki / Auntie Pearl
  • Kristen Trucksess as Stacy
  • Lochner de Kock as Professor Ovid Galba / Paddy Mahoney
  • Deep Roy as Mambino, The Boss of Bosses

Production ðŸ”—

Albert Pyun took on Alien from L.A. after being approached by producers Yoram Globus and Menahem Golan during the troubled production of Journey to the Center of the Earth. Pyun agreed to finish the film if he could also film Alien from L.A. for under $1 million. Kathy Ireland was cast by Pyun after seeing a photo of her. Filming locations included Los Angeles, Redondo Beach, South Africa, and Namibia. The gold mines and dumps around South Africa were used for the underground setpieces. The sets were inspired by “future noir” films like Alien and Blade Runner.

Release ðŸ”—

Alien from L.A. was released on February 26, 1988. It was released on VHS in June 1995 and on DVD in June 2005. Vinegar Syndrome has released a Blu-ray edition with special features. A direct-to-video sequel, Journey to the Center of the Earth, also directed by Albert Pyun and starring Kathy Ireland, was released in 1989.

Reception ðŸ”—

Joe Bob Briggs called it a “pretty decent film”, awarding it two stars. Rebecca Harris of the Abilene Reporter-News gave the film 2.5 stars out of 4. David Picking called it “a cheapo adventure movie without a single redeeming quality”. Rob Thomas of The Capital Times said “Completely awful â€“ you can’t believe they’re serious.” Daniel M. Kimmel of the Worcester Telegram & Gazette gave the film one out of five stars.

This is a description of the 1978 science fiction horror film The Alien Factor, directed, written, and produced by Don Dohler.

Plot ðŸ”—

The plot centers around a spaceship crash in a sparsely populated area of Earth. Three grotesque aliens survive the crash and begin terrorizing the local residents. A character named Ben Zachary steps forward to fight back against the extraterrestrial threat.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main cast includes:

Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino played the aliens Inferbyce and Zagatile, respectively.

Production ðŸ”—

The Alien Factor marked Don Dohler’s directorial debut after he was laid off from his job as a payroll manager. The initial script was a comedy with 15 monsters, but it was changed to a straight horror film with only three monsters. Larry Schlechter and John Cosentino built the creature suits for the Inferbyce and Zagtile, respectively. Ernest D. Farino created the Leemoid through stop motion animation. Filming took place in and around Baltimore, Maryland, from October 1976 to April 1977.

The film was released on DVD by Retromedia Entertainment on February 26, 2002. Image Entertainment released it on November 15, 2005, as part of the Don Dohler Collection. Mill Creek Entertainment released it on July 19, 2011.

The film received generally negative reviews. TV Guide gave it two out of five stars, calling it “silly.” Dave Sindelar criticized the acting and direction. Critical Outcast acknowledged the film’s flaws but admired Dohler’s initiative. VideoHound’s Golden Movie Retriever awarded it one and a half out of four bones, noting the decent special effects.

The Alien Factor 2: Alien Rampage was not a direct sequel. Fred Olen Ray, the Retromedia distributor, used the sequel-sounding title for marketing purposes. The original title was Alien Rampage, filmed in 1999 as Don Dohler’s comeback movie after an 11-year hiatus.

item.title: Outline of extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life: An Overview ðŸ”—

This outline provides a structured guide to understanding extraterrestrial life, encompassing its search, requirements, potential locations, possible traits, related ideas, fringe theories, media, influential figures, and fictional representations.

Search ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the scientific and organized search for life beyond Earth. Key areas include:

  • Astrobiology: The interdisciplinary field studying the possibilities of life in the universe.
  • Mars: Exploration efforts and experiments conducted on Mars, including the Viking lander biological experiments, to detect signs of life.
  • Meteorites: Analysis of meteorites like Allan Hills 77005, Allan Hills 84001, Murchison, Nakhla, Shergotty, and Yamato 000593 for potential biosignatures.
  • Biosignatures: The search for indicators of past or present life, such as the red edge phenomenon.
  • Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI): Projects like Active SETI, the Allen Telescope Array, Project Phoenix, and SERENDIP, which aim to detect intelligent signals from other civilizations. The section also mentions technosignatures and xenoarchaeology.
  • Communication with Extraterrestrial Intelligence (CETI): Attempts to communicate with potential extraterrestrial civilizations, including the Arecibo message and the study of astrolinguistics. The Wow! signal is also mentioned.

Likely Requirements ðŸ”—

This section outlines the conditions considered necessary for life to arise and thrive:

  • Circumstellar Habitable Zone: The region around a star where conditions allow for liquid water on a planet’s surface.
  • Extraterrestrial Liquid Water: The importance of liquid water as a solvent for biochemical reactions.
  • Planetary Habitability: The factors that make a planet suitable for life.

Potential Locations ðŸ”—

This section explores various celestial bodies and systems where life might exist:

  • Colonization of Europa: Discusses the possibility of establishing a human presence on Jupiter’s moon Europa.
  • Habitability of K-type Main-Sequence Star Systems: Examines the suitability of K-type stars for supporting habitable planets.
  • Habitability of Natural Satellites: Considers the potential for moons to host life.
  • Habitability of Red Dwarf Systems: Assesses the challenges and possibilities of life around red dwarf stars.
  • Habitable Exoplanets: Focuses on exoplanets that may possess conditions suitable for life, including Earth analogs and superhabitable planets.
  • Life on Mars, Titan, and Venus: Explores the potential for life on these specific bodies within our solar system.
  • Life Origination Beyond Planets: Considers the possibility of life arising in non-planetary environments.
  • Catalogs: Mentions the Catalog of Nearby Habitable Systems.

Possible Traits ðŸ”—

This section delves into the potential characteristics of extraterrestrial life:

  • Extraterrestrial Intelligence: The possibility of intelligent life beyond Earth and the study of alien languages.
  • Hypothetical Types of Biochemistry: Explores alternative biochemical systems, including carbon-based life and the role of CHON elements.
  • Extremophiles: Organisms that thrive in extreme environments, suggesting that life could exist in a wider range of conditions than previously thought.

Ideas ðŸ”—

This section presents key concepts and thought experiments related to extraterrestrial life:

  • Anthropocentrism: The idea that humans are the central or most significant entities in the universe.
  • Carbon Chauvinism: The assumption that life must be based on carbon.
  • Copernican Principle: The idea that Earth is not in a special or privileged position in the universe.
  • Cosmic Pluralism: The belief that there are many inhabited worlds in the universe.
  • Drake Equation: A probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.
  • Fermi Paradox: The apparent contradiction between the high probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of contact. Solutions include the Aestivation hypothesis, Great Filter, Rare Earth hypothesis, and Zoo hypothesis.
  • Fine-Tuned Universe: The idea that the universe’s physical constants are precisely tuned to allow for life.
  • Kardashev Scale: A method of classifying civilizations based on their energy consumption, including the concept of a Dyson sphere.
  • Mediocrity Principle: The idea that Earth is a typical planet and that life is likely common in the universe.
  • Potential Cultural Impact of Extraterrestrial Contact: Explores the potential societal and cultural effects of discovering extraterrestrial life, including exotheology and post-detection policy.

Fringe and Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section covers less mainstream perspectives on extraterrestrial life:

  • Ufology: The study of unidentified flying objects (UFOs), including alien abduction claims, close encounters, contactees, the extraterrestrial hypothesis, and UFO religions.
  • Ancient Astronauts: The pseudoscientific belief that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in the past and influenced ancient civilizations.

Extraterrestrial Life Media ðŸ”—

This section lists nonfiction books and documentaries related to extraterrestrial life, including:

  • Alien Oceans
  • Cosmos (Sagan book)
  • Evolving the Alien
  • Extraterrestrial: The First Sign of Intelligent Life Beyond Earth
  • Rare Earth: Why Complex Life Is Uncommon in the Universe
  • Cosmos: Possible Worlds

Persons Influential in Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This section highlights individuals who have made significant contributions to the field:

  • Giordano Bruno
  • Frank Drake
  • Enrico Fermi
  • Michael H. Hart
  • Stephen Hawking
  • Avi Loeb
  • Carl Sagan
  • Peter Ward

Extraterrestrial Life in Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the portrayal of extraterrestrial life in fictional works:

  • Extraterrestrials in Fiction: Covers alien languages, ancient astronauts in popular culture, and general representations of extraterrestrials.
  • List of Fictional Extraterrestrials: Provides links to lists of alien races in various fictional universes, including DC Comics, Marvel Comics, Star Trek, and Star Wars.
  • Archetypes: Describes common alien archetypes, such as bug-eyed monsters, elder races, energy beings, grey aliens, insectoids, and little green men.
  • Plots: Outlines common plot devices involving extraterrestrials, including alien invasions, Big Dumb Objects, first contact scenarios, interstellar wars, space warfare, and space travel.
